912750_13_ITEM8_P18_S0	The functional currency for all of our foreign operations is the U.S. dollar.
912750_13_ITEM8_P18_S1	Other on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P19_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents Cash and cash equivalents include highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when acquired and are stated at cost, which approximates fair value.
912750_13_ITEM8_P19_S1	We invest cash in excess of near-term capital and operating requirements in U.S. Treasury Notes, Eurodollar time deposits and money market funds, which are classified as cash and cash equivalents on our consolidated balance sheet.
912750_13_ITEM8_P19_S2	Investments Investments consist primarily of debt and equity securities, as well as auction rate securities, a majority of which are classified as available-for-sale and stated at fair value.
912750_13_ITEM8_P19_S3	Accordingly, unrealized gains and losses and the related deferred income tax effects are excluded from earnings and reported as a separate component within the consolidated statement of comprehensive income.
912750_13_ITEM8_P20_S0	Realized gains or losses are computed based on specific identification of the securities sold.
912750_13_ITEM8_P20_S1	We regularly assess our investments for impairment and consider any impairment to be other than temporary if we intend to sell the security, it is more likely than not that we will be required to sell the security, or we do not expect to recover our cost of the security.
912750_13_ITEM8_P20_S2	We realized interest income and net gains on our investment securities in 2012, 2011 and 2010 of $3 million, $2 million and $1 million, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P21_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts We routinely assess the recoverability of all material trade and other receivables to determine their collectability.
912750_13_ITEM8_P22_S0	Many of our receivables are from joint interest owners of properties we operate.
912750_13_ITEM8_P22_S1	Thus, we may have the ability to withhold future revenue disbursements to recover any non-payment of joint interest billings.
912750_13_ITEM8_P22_S2	Generally, our oil and gas receivables are collected within 45 to 60 days of production.
912750_13_ITEM8_P23_S0	We accrue a reserve on a receivable when, based on the judgment of management, it is probable that a receivable will not be collected and the amount of the reserve may be reasonably estimated.
912750_13_ITEM8_P24_S0	Inventories Inventories primarily consist of tubular goods and well equipment held for use in our oil and natural gas operations and oil produced but not sold in our offshore operations in Malaysia and China.
912750_13_ITEM8_P24_S1	Inventories are carried at the lower of cost or market.
912750_13_ITEM8_P25_S0	At December 31, 2012, we wrote down subsea wellhead inventory that was not included in the sale of our Gulf of Mexico assets.
912750_13_ITEM8_P25_S1	The writedown of $8 million is included in Operating expenses Other on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P26_S0	Substantially all of the crude oil from our offshore operations in Malaysia and China is produced into floating production, storage and off-loading vessels (FPSOs) or onshore storage terminals and lifted and sold periodically as barge quantities are accumulated.
912750_13_ITEM8_P26_S1	The product inventory consisted of approximately 744,000 barrels and 239,000 barrels of crude oil valued at cost of $64 million and $19 million at December 31, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P26_S2	Cost for purposes of the carrying value of oil inventory is the sum of production costs and depletion expense.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S0	Oil and Gas Properties We use the full cost method of accounting for our oil and gas producing activities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S1	Under this method, all costs incurred in the acquisition, exploration and development of oil and gas properties, including salaries, benefits and other internal costs directly attributable to these activities, are capitalized into cost centers that are established on a country-by-country basis.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S2	We capitalized $123 million, $113 million and $79 million of internal costs in 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S3	Interest expense related to unproved properties is also capitalized into oil and gas properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S4	Proceeds from the sale of oil and gas properties are applied to reduce the costs in the applicable cost center unless the reduction would significantly alter the relationship between capitalized costs and proved reserves, in which case a gain or loss is recognized.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S5	Capitalized costs and estimated future development costs are amortized using a unit-of-production method based on proved reserves associated with the applicable cost center.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S6	For each cost center, the net capitalized costs of oil and gas properties are limited to the lower of the unamortized cost or the cost center ceiling.
912750_13_ITEM8_P27_S7	A particular cost center ceiling is equal to the sum of:
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S0	If net capitalized costs of oil and gas properties exceed the cost center ceiling, we are subject to a ceiling test writedown to the extent of such excess.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S1	If required, a ceiling test writedown reduces earnings and stockholders equity in the period of occurrence and, holding other factors constant, results in lower depreciation, depletion and amortization expense in future periods.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S2	The risk that we will be required to writedown the carrying value of our oil and gas properties, increases when oil, gas and NGL prices decrease significantly for a prolonged period of time or if we have substantial downward revisions in our estimated proved reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S3	At December 31, 2012, the ceiling value of our reserves was calculated based upon SEC pricing of $2.76 per MMBtu for natural gas and $94.84 per barrel for oil.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S4	Using these prices, the unamortized net capitalized costs of our domestic oil and gas properties exceeded the ceiling amount by approximately $1.5 billion ($948 million, after-tax).
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S5	The ceiling with respect to our properties in Malaysia and China exceeded the net capitalized costs of properties, requiring no writedown at December 31, 2012.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S6	The continued decline of SEC pricing of oil and natural gas since December 31, 2012 may result in additional ceiling test writedowns in the first quarter of 2013 and possibly thereafter.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S7	At December 31, 2011, the ceiling value of our reserves was calculated based upon SEC pricing of $4.12 per MMBtu for natural gas and $96.13 per barrel for oil.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S8	Using these prices, the cost center ceilings with respect to our properties in the U.S., Malaysia and China exceeded the net capitalized costs of the respective properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P28_S9	As such, no ceiling test writedowns were required at December 31, 2011.
912750_13_ITEM8_P29_S0	At December 31, 2010, the ceiling value of our reserves was calculated based upon SEC pricing of $4.38 per MMBtu for natural gas and $79.42 per barrel for oil.
912750_13_ITEM8_P29_S1	Using these prices, the cost center ceilings with respect to our properties in the U.S., Malaysia and China exceeded the net capitalized costs of the respective properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P29_S2	As such, no ceiling test writedowns were required at December 31, 2010.
912750_13_ITEM8_P30_S0	See Note 3, Oil and Gas Assets, for a detailed discussion regarding our acquisition and sales transactions during 2012, 2011 and 2010.
912750_13_ITEM8_P31_S0	Other Property and Equipment Furniture, fixtures and equipment are recorded at cost and are depreciated using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives, which range from three to seven years.
912750_13_ITEM8_P32_S0	If a reasonable estimate of the fair value of an obligation to perform site reclamation, dismantle facilities or plug and abandon wells can be made, we record a liability (an asset retirement obligation or ARO) on our consolidated balance sheet and capitalize the present value of the asset retirement cost in oil and gas properties in the period in which the ARO is incurred.
912750_13_ITEM8_P32_S1	Settlements include payments made to satisfy the AROs, as well as transfer of the ARO to purchasers of our divested properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P32_S2	In general, the amount of an ARO and the costs capitalized will equal the estimated future cost to satisfy the abandonment obligation assuming the normal operation of the asset, using current prices that are escalated by an assumed inflation factor up to the estimated settlement date, which is then discounted back to the date that the abandonment obligation was incurred using an assumed cost of funds for our Company.
912750_13_ITEM8_P32_S3	After recording these amounts, the ARO is accreted to its future estimated value using the same assumed cost of funds and the original capitalized costs are depreciated on a unit-of-production basis within the related full cost pool.
912750_13_ITEM8_P32_S4	Both the accretion and the depreciation are included in depreciation, depletion and amortization expense on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P32_S5	The change in our ARO for each of the three years ended December 31, is set forth below:
912750_13_ITEM8_P33_S0	(1) For the year ended December 31, 2012, settlements include $28 million related to the sale of our Gulf of Mexico assets.
912750_13_ITEM8_P33_S1	See Note 3, Oil and Gas Assets.
912750_13_ITEM8_P34_S0	Contingencies We are subject to legal proceedings, claims, liabilities and environmental matters that arise in the ordinary course of business.
912750_13_ITEM8_P34_S1	We accrue for losses when such losses are considered probable and the amounts can be reasonably estimated.
912750_13_ITEM8_P34_S2	See Note 12, Commitments and Contingencies, for a more detailed discussion regarding our contingencies.
912750_13_ITEM8_P35_S0	Environmental Matters Environmental costs that relate to current operations are expensed as incurred.
912750_13_ITEM8_P35_S1	Remediation costs that relate to an existing condition caused by past operations are accrued when it is probable that those costs will be incurred and can be reasonably estimated based upon evaluations of currently available facts related to each site.
912750_13_ITEM8_P36_S0	Income Taxes We use the liability method of accounting for income taxes.
912750_13_ITEM8_P36_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined by applying tax regulations existing at the end of a reporting period to the cumulative temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their reported amounts in our financial statements.
912750_13_ITEM8_P37_S0	A valuation allowance is established to reduce deferred tax assets if it is more likely than not that the related tax benefits will not be realized.
912750_13_ITEM8_P37_S1	As of December 31, 2012, we did not have a liability for uncertain tax positions and as such we had not accrued related interest or penalties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P37_S2	The tax years 2009-2012 remain open to examination for federal income tax purposes and by the other major taxing jurisdictions to which we are subject.
912750_13_ITEM8_P38_S0	Stock-Based Compensation We apply a fair value-based method of accounting for stock-based compensation which requires recognition in the financial statements of the cost of services received in exchange for awards of equity instruments based on the grant date fair value of those awards.
912750_13_ITEM8_P38_S1	For equity-based compensation awards, compensation expense is based on the fair value on the grant or modification date and is recognized in our financial statements over the vesting period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P39_S0	We utilize the Black-Scholes option-pricing model to measure the fair value of stock options and a lattice-based model for our performance and market-based restricted stock and restricted stock units.
912750_13_ITEM8_P39_S1	Additionally in 2011, we granted cash-settled restricted stock units that are accounted for under the liability method which requires us to recognize the fair value of each award based on the underlying share price at the end of each period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P39_S2	See Note 10, Stock-Based Compensation, for a full discussion of our stock-based compensation.
912750_13_ITEM8_P40_S0	Concentration of Credit Risk We operate a substantial portion of our oil and gas properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P40_S1	As the operator of a property, we make full payment for costs associated with the property and seek reimbursement from the other working interest owners in the property for their share of those costs.
912750_13_ITEM8_P40_S2	Our joint interest partners consist primarily of independent oil and gas producers.
912750_13_ITEM8_P40_S3	If the oil and gas exploration and production industry in general was adversely affected, the ability of our joint interest partners to reimburse us could be adversely affected.
912750_13_ITEM8_P41_S0	The purchasers of our oil, gas and NGL production consist primarily of independent marketers, major oil and gas companies, refiners and gas pipeline companies.
912750_13_ITEM8_P41_S1	We perform credit evaluations of the purchasers of our production and monitor their financial condition on an ongoing basis.
912750_13_ITEM8_P41_S2	Based on our evaluations and monitoring, we obtain cash escrows, letters of credit or parental guarantees from some purchasers.
912750_13_ITEM8_P42_S0	Historically, we have sold our oil, gas and NGLs to several purchasers.
912750_13_ITEM8_P42_S1	All of our hedging transactions have been carried out in the over-the-counter market.
912750_13_ITEM8_P43_S0	The use of hedging transactions involves the risk that the counterparties will be unable to meet the financial terms of such transactions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P43_S1	The counterparties for all of our hedging transactions have an investment grade credit rating.
912750_13_ITEM8_P43_S2	We monitor the credit ratings of our hedging counterparties on an ongoing basis.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S0	our counterparties were to default on its obligations to us under the hedging contracts or seek bankruptcy protection, it could have a material adverse effect on our ability to fund our planned activities and could result in a larger percentage of our future production being subject to commodity price changes.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S1	In addition, in poor economic environments and tight financial markets, the risk of a counterparty default is heightened and fewer counterparties may participate in hedging transactions, which could result in greater concentration of our exposure to any one counterparty or a larger percentage of our future production being subject to commodity price changes.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S2	At December 31, 2012, seven of our 15 counterparties accounted for approximately 85% of our estimated future hedged production, with no single counterparty accounting for more than 25% of that production.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S3	Major Customers Royal Dutch Shell plc, Tesoro Corporation and Big West Oil LLC accounted for 14%, 14% and 10% respectively, of our consolidated revenues in 2012.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S4	During 2011, sales of our oil and gas production to Royal Dutch Shell plc and Tesoro Corporation accounted for 12% and 11%, respectively, of our consolidated revenues.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S5	No single customer accounted for 10% or more of our sales of oil and gas production during 2010.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S6	We believe that the loss of Royal Dutch Shell plc would not have a material adverse effect on us because alternative purchasers are readily available.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S7	An extended loss of Tesoro Corporation, Big West Oil LLC, or any of our other large purchasers of our Monument Butte field oil production could have a material adverse effect on us because there are limited purchasers of the black and yellow wax crude oil, which we produce from this field.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S8	Due to the higher paraffin content of this production, it must remain heated during shipping so it cannot be transported in conventional pipelines, and there is limited refining capacity for it in the vicinity of our production.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S9	In poor economic environments and tight financial markets, there is an increased risk that the current purchasers of our production may fail to satisfy their obligations to us under our crude oil purchase contracts.
912750_13_ITEM8_P44_S10	We cannot guarantee that we will be able to continue to sell to these purchasers or that similar substitute arrangements could be made for sales of our black and yellow wax crude oil with other purchasers if desired.
912750_13_ITEM8_P45_S0	Derivative Financial Instruments We account for our derivative activities by applying authoritative accounting and reporting guidance, which requires that every derivative instrument be recorded on the consolidated balance sheet as either an asset or a liability measured at its fair value and that changes in the derivative s fair value be recognized currently in earnings unless specific hedge accounting criteria are met.
912750_13_ITEM8_P45_S1	All of the derivative instruments that we utilize are to manage the price risk attributable to our expected oil and gas production.
912750_13_ITEM8_P45_S2	We have elected not to designate price-risk management activities as accounting hedges under the accounting guidance and, accordingly, account for them using the mark-to-market accounting method.
912750_13_ITEM8_P46_S0	Under this method, the changes in contract values are reported currently in earnings.
912750_13_ITEM8_P47_S0	We periodically utilize derivatives to manage our exposure to variable interest rates.
912750_13_ITEM8_P47_S1	The related cash flow impact of our derivative activities are reflected as cash flows from operating activities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P47_S2	See Note 4, Derivative Financial Instruments, for a more detailed discussion of our derivative activities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P48_S0	Comprehensive Income (Loss) Comprehensive income (loss) includes net income (loss) as well as unrealized gains and losses on investments and changes in post-retirement benefits, all recorded net of tax.
912750_13_ITEM8_P48_S1	As of December 31, 2012, accumulated other comprehensive loss consisted of a $6 million unrealized loss on investments and a $1 million unrealized loss on post-retirement benefits.
912750_13_ITEM8_P48_S2	As of December 31, 2011, accumulated other comprehensive loss consisted of an $8 million unrealized loss on investments and a $2 million unrealized loss on post-retirement benefits.
912750_13_ITEM8_P49_S0	In December 2011, the FASB issued guidance regarding the disclosure of offsetting assets and liabilities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P49_S1	The guidance will require disclosure of gross information and net information about instruments and transactions eligible for offset arrangement.
912750_13_ITEM8_P49_S2	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013.
912750_13_ITEM8_P49_S3	We do not expect adoption of the additional disclosures about offsetting assets and liabilities to have a material impact on our financial position or results of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P50_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued guidance impacting the presentation of comprehensive income.
912750_13_ITEM8_P50_S1	The guidance eliminates the current option to report components of other comprehensive income in the statement of changes in equity.
912750_13_ITEM8_P50_S2	The guidance is intended to provide a more consistent method of presenting non-owner transactions that affect an entity s equity.
912750_13_ITEM8_P50_S3	The guidance is retrospective and effective for interim and annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2011.
912750_13_ITEM8_P50_S4	We adopted the provisions for the quarter ended March 31, 2012.
912750_13_ITEM8_P51_S0	Adopting the reporting requirements did not have a material impact on our financial position or results of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P51_S1	In May 2011, the FASB issued additional guidance regarding fair value measurement and disclosure requirements.
912750_13_ITEM8_P51_S2	The most significant change required, for Level 3 fair value measurements, disclosure of quantitative information about unobservable inputs used, a description of the valuation processes used, and a qualitative discussion about the sensitivity of the measurements.
912750_13_ITEM8_P51_S3	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2011.
912750_13_ITEM8_P51_S4	We adopted the provisions for the quarter ended March 31, 2012.
912750_13_ITEM8_P52_S0	Adopting the additional fair value measurement and disclosure requirements did not have a material impact on our financial position or results of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P53_S0	Basic earnings per share (EPS) is calculated by dividing net income (the numerator) by the weighted-average number of shares of common stock (excluding unvested restricted stock and restricted stock units) outstanding during the period (the denominator).
912750_13_ITEM8_P53_S1	Diluted earnings per share incorporates the dilutive impact of outstanding stock options and unvested restricted stock and restricted stock units (using the treasury stock method).
912750_13_ITEM8_P53_S2	Under the treasury stock method, the amount the employee must pay for exercising stock options, the amount of unrecognized compensation expense related to unvested stock-based compensation grants and the amount of excess tax benefits that would be recorded when the award becomes deductible are assumed to be used to repurchase shares.
912750_13_ITEM8_P53_S3	Please see Note 10, Stock-Based Compensation.
912750_13_ITEM8_P54_S0	The following is the calculation of basic and diluted weighted-average shares outstanding and EPS for the indicated years:
912750_13_ITEM8_P55_S0	(1) The effect of stock options and unvested restricted stock and restricted stock units outstanding has not been included in the calculation of shares outstanding for diluted EPS for the year ended December 31, 2012 as their effect would have been anti-dilutive.
912750_13_ITEM8_P55_S1	Had we recognized net income for that year, incremental shares attributable to the assumed exercise of outstanding options and the assumed vesting of unvested restricted stock and restricted stock units would have increased diluted weighted-average shares outstanding by 0.7 million shares for the year.
912750_13_ITEM8_P56_S0	(2) The calculation of shares outstanding for diluted EPS for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010 excludes the effect of 1.4 million and 0.7 million, respectively, unvested restricted stock or restricted stock units and stock options because including the effect would be anti-dilutive.
912750_13_ITEM8_P57_S0	Oil and Gas Assets: Property and Equipment Property and equipment consisted of the following at December 31: Oil and gas properties not subject to amortization represent investments in unproved properties and major development projects in which we own an interest.
912750_13_ITEM8_P57_S1	These unproved property costs include unevaluated leasehold acreage, geological and geophysical data costs associated with leasehold or drilling interests, costs associated with wells in progress at December 31 and capitalized interest.
912750_13_ITEM8_P57_S2	We exclude these costs on a country-by-country basis until proved reserves are found or until it is determined that the costs are impaired.
912750_13_ITEM8_P58_S0	Unproved property costs are grouped by major prospect area where individual property costs are not significant and are assessed individually when individual costs are significant.
912750_13_ITEM8_P58_S1	Costs associated with wells in progress are transferred to the amortization base upon the determination of whether proved reserves can be assigned to the properties, which is generally based on drilling results.
912750_13_ITEM8_P58_S2	All other costs excluded from the amortization base are reviewed quarterly to determine if impairment has occurred.
912750_13_ITEM8_P58_S3	The amount of any impairment is transferred to the amortization base or a charge is made against earnings for international operations if a reserve base has not yet been established.
912750_13_ITEM8_P59_S0	The following is a summary of our oil and gas properties not subject to amortization as of December 31, 2012.
912750_13_ITEM8_P59_S1	We believe that our evaluation activities related to substantially all of our conventional properties not subject to amortization will be completed within four years.
912750_13_ITEM8_P59_S2	Because of the size of our unconventional resource plays, the entire evaluation will take significantly longer than four years.
912750_13_ITEM8_P60_S0	At December 31, 2012, approximately 85% of oil and gas properties not subject to amortization were associated with our unconventional resource plays.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S0	Gulf of Mexico Asset Sale On October 5, 2012, we closed on the sale of our remaining assets in the Gulf of Mexico to W T Offshore, Inc. for approximately $208 million, subject to customary post-closing adjustments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S1	The sale of our remaining assets in the Gulf of Mexico did not significantly alter the relationship between capitalized costs and proved reserves and as such, all proceeds were recorded as adjustments to our domestic full cost pool with no gain or loss recognized.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S2	These consolidated financial statements include the results of our Gulf of Mexico operations through the date of sale.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S3	In May 2011, we closed two transactions to acquire assets in the Uinta basin of Utah for a total of approximately $303 million (includes $4 million in purchase price adjustments).
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S4	The assets include approximately 65,000 net acres, which are largely undeveloped and located north of our Greater Monument Butte Unit.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S5	In February 2010, we acquired certain of TXCO Resources Inc. s assets in the Maverick basin of southwest Texas for approximately $205 million.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S6	In the acquisition, we obtained an interest in approximately 300,000 net acres, primarily in the Pearsall and Eagle Ford shale plays, as well as production of 1,500 barrels of oil equivalent per day.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S7	Our consolidated financial statements include the cash flows and results of operations for these assets subsequent to the acquisition date.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S8	Other Asset Acquisitions and Sales During 2012, 2011 and 2010, we acquired various other oil and gas properties for approximately $9 million, $1 million and $108 million, respectively, and sold various other non-strategic oil and gas properties for proceeds of approximately $630 million (includes Gulf of Mexico asset sale discussed above), $406 million and $12 million, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S9	The cash flows and results of operations for the assets included in a sale are included in our consolidated financial statements up to the date of sale.
912750_13_ITEM8_P61_S10	All of the proceeds associated with our asset sales were recorded as adjustments to our domestic full cost pool.
912750_13_ITEM8_P62_S0	We utilize fixed price swaps, purchased put options (floors), collars (combination of purchased put options and sold call options (ceiling)) and three-way collars (combination of a collar and the sale of additional put options with a strike price below the floor of the collar) to hedge against the variability in cash flows associated with the forecasted sale of our future oil and gas production.
912750_13_ITEM8_P62_S1	While the use of these derivative instruments limits the downside risk of adverse price movements, their use also may limit future income from favorable price movements.
912750_13_ITEM8_P63_S0	With respect to a swap contract, the counterparty is required to make a payment to us if the settlement price for any settlement period is less than the swap price, and we are required to make a payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any settlement period is greater than the swap price.
912750_13_ITEM8_P63_S1	For a floor contract, the counterparty is required to make a payment to us if the settlement price for any settlement period is below the floor price.
912750_13_ITEM8_P63_S2	We are not required to make any payment in connection with the settlement of a floor contract.
912750_13_ITEM8_P63_S3	For a collar contract, the counterparty is required to make a payment to us if the settlement price for any settlement period is below the floor price while we are required to make payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any settlement period is above the ceiling price.
912750_13_ITEM8_P63_S4	Neither party is required to make a payment to the other party if the settlement price for any settlement period is equal to or greater than the floor price and equal to or less than the ceiling price.
912750_13_ITEM8_P64_S0	A three-way collar contract consists of a standard collar contract plus a put sold by us with a price below the floor price of the collar.
912750_13_ITEM8_P64_S1	This additional put requires us to make a payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any settlement period is below the put price.
912750_13_ITEM8_P64_S2	Combining the collar contract with the additional put results in us being entitled to a net payment equal to the difference between the floor price of the standard collar and the additional put price if the settlement price is equal to or less than the additional put price.
912750_13_ITEM8_P64_S3	If the settlement price is greater than the additional put price, the result is the same as it would have been with a standard collar contract only.
912750_13_ITEM8_P64_S4	This strategy enables us to increase the floor and the ceiling price of the collar beyond the range of a traditional no cost collar while defraying the associated cost with the sale of the additional put.
912750_13_ITEM8_P65_S0	All of our derivative contracts are carried at their fair value on our consolidated balance sheet under the captions Derivative assets and Derivative liabilities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P65_S1	Substantially all of our oil and gas derivative contracts are settled based upon reported prices on the NYMEX.
912750_13_ITEM8_P65_S2	The estimated fair value of these contracts is based upon various factors, including closing exchange prices on the NYMEX, over-the-counter quotations, estimated volatility and, in the case of collars and floors, the remaining term of options.
912750_13_ITEM8_P65_S3	The calculation of the fair value of collars and floors requires the use of an option-pricing model.
912750_13_ITEM8_P65_S4	Please see Note 7, Fair Value Measurements.
912750_13_ITEM8_P66_S0	We recognize all realized and unrealized gains and losses related to these contracts on a mark-to-market basis in our consolidated statement of operations under the caption Commodity derivative income.
912750_13_ITEM8_P66_S1	Settlements of derivative contracts are included in operating cash flows on our consolidated statement of cash flows.
912750_13_ITEM8_P67_S0	At December 31, 2012, we had outstanding contracts with respect to our future production that were not designated for hedge accounting as set forth in the tables below.
912750_13_ITEM8_P68_S0	During the first quarter of 2012, natural gas spot market prices were below the puts we sold on our three-way collars for April through December 2012 and the full-year 2013, exposing us further to the softening natural gas spot market.
912750_13_ITEM8_P68_S1	As a result, during the first quarter of 2012 we entered into additional fixed-price swap contracts in the over-the-counter market that effectively prevented any further erosion in the value of our natural gas three-way collars.
912750_13_ITEM8_P68_S2	The new swap contracts added during the first quarter of 2012 were for the same volumes as our full-year 2013 three-way collar contracts.
912750_13_ITEM8_P68_S3	The economics from the combination of these additional fixed-price swap contracts and our natural gas three-way collar contracts will result in effective average fixed prices of $4.96, $4.82.
912750_13_ITEM8_P68_S4	$4.82 and $4.86 per MMBtu for the first, second, third and fourth quarter of 2013, respectively, as long as natural gas spot prices for the respective time periods settle below the puts we sold on our three-way collar contracts.
912750_13_ITEM8_P68_S5	In the event natural gas spot prices settle above the ceilings on our associated three-way collar volumes, we would not recover the difference through the sale of our production as we would realize losses on both instruments discussed above.
912750_13_ITEM8_P69_S0	Interest Rate Swap We previously hedged $50 million principal amount of our $175 million 7 5 / 8 % Senior Notes due 2011 through an interest rate swap.
912750_13_ITEM8_P69_S1	The swap provided for us to pay variable and receive fixed payments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P69_S2	During the first half of 2010, we repurchased our outstanding 7 5 / 8 % Senior Notes due 2011 and received approximately $2 million upon the termination and settlement of the swap.
912750_13_ITEM8_P70_S0	We had derivative financial instruments recorded in our consolidated balance sheet as assets (liabilities) at their respective estimated fair value, as set forth below at December 31:
912750_13_ITEM8_P71_S0	The amount of gain (loss) recognized in Commodity derivative income in our consolidated statement of operations related to our derivative financial instruments was as follows at December 31:
912750_13_ITEM8_P71_S1	The total realized gain on commodity derivatives for the year ended December 31, 2010 differs from the net cash receipts on derivative settlements due to the recognition of option premiums associated with derivatives settled during the respective period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P72_S0	The use of derivative transactions involves the risk that the counterparties will be unable to meet the financial terms of such transactions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P72_S1	Our derivative contracts are with multiple counterparties to minimize our exposure to any individual counterparty, and we have netting arrangements with all of our counterparties that provide for offsetting payables against receivables from separate derivative instruments with that counterparty.
912750_13_ITEM8_P72_S2	At December 31, 2012, seven of our 15 counterparties accounted for approximately 85% of our estimated future hedged production, with no single counterparty accounting for more than 25% of that production.
912750_13_ITEM8_P72_S3	A significant portion of our derivative instruments are with lenders under our credit facility.
912750_13_ITEM8_P72_S4	Our credit facility, senior notes, senior subordinated notes and substantially all of our derivative instruments contain provisions that provide for cross defaults and acceleration of those debt and derivative instruments in certain situations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P73_S0	Accounts receivable consisted of the following at December 31:
912750_13_ITEM8_P74_S0	6. Accrued Liabilities: Accrued liabilities consisted of the following at December 31:
912750_13_ITEM8_P75_S0	Fair Value Measurements: Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
912750_13_ITEM8_P75_S1	The authoritative guidance requires disclosure of the framework for measuring fair value and requires that fair value measurements be classified and disclosed in one of the following categories:
912750_13_ITEM8_P76_S0	Level 1: Unadjusted quoted prices in active markets that are accessible at the measurement date for identical, unrestricted assets or liabilities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P76_S1	We consider active markets as those in which transactions for the assets or liabilities occur with sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis.
912750_13_ITEM8_P77_S0	Level 2: Quoted prices in markets that are not active, or inputs that are observable, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
912750_13_ITEM8_P77_S1	This category includes those derivative instruments that we value using observable market data.
912750_13_ITEM8_P77_S2	Substantially all of these inputs are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the derivative instrument, can be derived from observable data or supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
912750_13_ITEM8_P78_S0	Instruments in this category include non-exchange traded derivatives such as over-the-counter commodity price swaps and certain investments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P79_S0	Level 3: Measured based on prices or valuation models that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and less observable from objective sources (i.e., supported by little or no market activity).
912750_13_ITEM8_P80_S0	Our valuation models for derivative contracts are primarily industry-standard models (i.e., Black-Scholes) that consider various inputs including: (a) quoted forward prices for commodities, (b) time value, (c) volatility factors, (d) counterparty credit risk and (e) current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
912750_13_ITEM8_P80_S1	Our valuation methodology for investments is a discounted cash flow model that considers various inputs including: (a) the coupon rate specified under the debt instruments, (b) the current credit ratings of the underlying issuers, (c) collateral characteristics and (d) risk-adjusted discount rates.
912750_13_ITEM8_P81_S0	Level 3 instruments primarily include derivative instruments, such as commodity options including, price collars, floors and three-way collars and other financial investments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P81_S1	Although we utilize third-party broker quotes to assess the reasonableness of our prices and valuation techniques for derivative instruments, we do not have sufficient corroborating market evidence to support classifying these assets and liabilities as Level 2.
912750_13_ITEM8_P82_S0	Financial assets and liabilities are classified based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
912750_13_ITEM8_P82_S1	Our assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment and may affect the valuation of the fair value of assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy levels.
912750_13_ITEM8_P83_S0	The following table summarizes the valuation of our financial assets (liabilities) by measurement levels:
912750_13_ITEM8_P84_S0	The determination of the fair values above incorporates various factors, which include not only the impact of our non-performance risk on our liabilities but also the credit standing of the counterparties involved and the impact of credit enhancements (such as cash deposits, letters of credit and priority interests), if any.
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S0	We utilize credit default swap values to assess the impact of non-performance risk when evaluating both our liabilities to and receivables from counterparties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S1	As of December 31, 2012, we held $36 million of auction rate securities maturing beginning in 2033 that are classified as a Level 3 fair value measurement.
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S2	This amount reflects a decrease in the fair value of these investments since the time of purchase of $9 million ($6 million net of tax) recorded under the caption Accumulated other comprehensive loss on our consolidated balance sheet.
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S3	As of December 31, 2011, we held $32 million of auction rate securities, which reflected a decrease in the fair value of $13 million ($8 million net of tax).
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S4	The debt instruments underlying our auction rate securities are mostly investment grade (rated BBB or better) and are guaranteed by the United States government or backed by private loan collateral.
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S5	We do not believe the decrease in the fair value of these securities is permanent because we currently intend to hold these investments until the auction succeeds, the issuer calls the securities or the securities mature.
912750_13_ITEM8_P85_S6	Our current available borrowing capacity under our credit arrangements provides us the liquidity to continue to hold these securities.
912750_13_ITEM8_P86_S0	The following table sets forth a reconciliation of changes in the fair value of financial assets and liabilities classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy for the indicated periods: Qualitative Disclosures about Unobservable Inputs for Level 3 Fair Value Measurements Commodity Derivatives.
912750_13_ITEM8_P87_S0	Our valuation models for derivative contracts are primarily industry-standard models that consider various factors, including certain significant unobservable inputs such as (a) quoted forward prices for commodities, (b) volatility factors and (c) counterparty credit risk.
912750_13_ITEM8_P88_S0	The calculation of the fair value of our option contracts requires the use of an option-pricing model.
912750_13_ITEM8_P88_S1	The estimated future prices are compared to the prices fixed by the hedge agreements and the resulting estimated future cash inflows or outflows over the lives of the hedges are discounted to calculate the fair value of the derivative contracts.
912750_13_ITEM8_P88_S2	These pricing and discounting variables are sensitive to market volatility as well as changes in future price forecasts, regional price differences and interest rates.
912750_13_ITEM8_P89_S0	Significant increases (decreases) in the quoted forward prices for commodities generally leads to corresponding decreases (increases) in the fair value measurement of our oil and gas derivative contracts.
912750_13_ITEM8_P90_S0	Significant changes in the volatility factors utilized in our option-pricing model can cause significant changes in the fair value measurement of our oil and gas derivative contracts.
912750_13_ITEM8_P91_S0	The determination of the fair values of derivative instruments incorporates various factors that include not only the impact of our non-performance risk on our liabilities but also the credit standing of the counterparties involved and the impact of credit enhancements (such as cash deposits, letters of credit and priority interests).
912750_13_ITEM8_P91_S1	Historically, we have not experienced significant changes in the fair value of our derivative contracts resulting from changes in counterparty credit risk as the counterparties for all of our hedging transactions have an investment grade credit rating.
912750_13_ITEM8_P92_S0	We utilize a discounted cash flow model in the determination of the valuation of our auction rate securities classified as Level 3.
912750_13_ITEM8_P92_S1	This model considers various inputs including (a) the coupon rate specified under the debt instrument, (b) the current credit rating of the underlying issuers, (c) collateral characteristics and (d) risk-adjusted discount rates.
912750_13_ITEM8_P92_S2	The most significant unobservable factor in the determination of the investments fair value, however, is market liquidity for these instruments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P92_S3	A significant change in the liquidity of the market for auction rate securities would lead to a corresponding change in the fair value measurement of these investments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P93_S0	The underlying inputs in the determination of the valuation of our auction rate securities are developed by a third party and, therefore, not included in the quantitative analysis above.

912750_13_ITEM8_P95_S0	Any amounts outstanding under our credit arrangements at December 31, 2012 and 2011 are stated at cost, which approximates fair value.
912750_13_ITEM8_P96_S0	At December 31, our debt consisted of the following:
912750_13_ITEM8_P97_S0	(1) Because capacity under our credit facility was available to repay borrowings under our money market lines of credit as of the indicated dates, amounts outstanding under these obligations, if any, are classified as long-term.
912750_13_ITEM8_P98_S0	We have a revolving credit facility that matures in June 2016.
912750_13_ITEM8_P98_S1	The terms of the credit facility provide for loan commitments of $1.25 billion from a syndicate of 13 financial institutions, led by JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as agent.
912750_13_ITEM8_P98_S2	In September 2011, we entered into the first amendment to the credit facility, which allows us to issue senior notes or other debt instruments that are secured equally and ratably with the credit facility.
912750_13_ITEM8_P99_S0	As of December 31, 2012, the largest individual loan commitment by any lender was 13% of total commitments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P100_S0	Loans under the credit facility bear interest, at our option, equal to (a) a rate per annum equal to the higher of the prime rate announced from time to time by JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. or the weighted average of the rates on overnight federal funds transactions with members of the Federal Reserve System during the last preceding business day plus 50 basis points, plus a margin that is based on a grid of our debt rating (75 basis points per annum at December 31, 2012) or (b) the London Interbank Offered Rate, plus a margin that is based on a grid of our debt rating (175 basis points per annum at December 31, 2012).
912750_13_ITEM8_P100_S1	Under our credit facility, we pay commitment fees on available but undrawn amounts based on a grid of our debt rating (30 basis points per annum at December 31, 2012).
912750_13_ITEM8_P100_S2	We incurred aggregate commitment fees under our current and previous credit facilities of approximately $3 million, $2 million and $2 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively, which are recorded in Interest expense on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P101_S0	Our credit facility has restrictive financial covenants that include the maintenance of a ratio of total debt to book capitalization not to exceed 0.6 to 1.0 and maintenance of a ratio of earnings before gain or loss on the disposition of assets, interest expense, income taxes and noncash items (such as depreciation, depletion and amortization expense, unrealized gains and losses on commodity derivatives, ceiling test writedowns and goodwill impairments) to interest expense of at least 3.0 to 1.0.
912750_13_ITEM8_P101_S1	At December 31, 2012, we were in compliance with all of our debt covenants.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S0	As of December 31, 2012, we had no letters of credit outstanding under our credit facility.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S1	Letters of credit are subject to a fronting fee of 20 basis points and annual fees based on a grid of our debt rating (175 basis points at December 31, 2012).
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S2	Additionally, as of December 31, 2012, we had $5 million of other undrawn letters of credit outstanding.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S3	Subject to compliance with the restrictive covenants in our credit facility, at December 31, 2012, we also had a total of $145 million of borrowing capacity under money market lines of credit with various financial institutions, the availability of which is at the discretion of the financial institutions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S4	The credit facility includes events of default relating to customary matters, including, among other things, nonpayment of principal, interest or other amounts; violation of covenants; inaccuracy of representations and warranties in any material respect; a change of control; or certain other material adverse changes in our business.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S5	Our senior notes and senior subordinated notes also contain standard events of default.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S6	If any of the foregoing defaults were to occur, our lenders under the credit facility could terminate future lending commitments, and our lenders under both the credit facility and our notes could declare the outstanding borrowings due and payable.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S7	In addition, our credit facility, senior notes, senior subordinated notes and substantially all of our hedging arrangements contain provisions that provide for cross defaults and acceleration of those debt and hedging instruments in certain situations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S8	Senior Notes In September 2011, we issued $750 million of 5 3 / 4 % Senior Notes due 2022 and received proceeds of $742 million (net of discount and offering costs).
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S9	These notes were issued at 99.956% of par to yield 5 3 / 4 %.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S10	We used the net proceeds to repay a portion of our then outstanding borrowings under our credit facility and money market lines of credit.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S11	In June 2012, we issued $1 billion of 5 5 / 8 % Senior Notes due 2024 and received proceeds of $990 million (net of offering costs).
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S12	These notes were issued at par to yield 5 5 / 8 %.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S13	We used a portion of the net proceeds to repay borrowings outstanding under our credit facility and money market lines of credit as well as redeem our 6 5 / 8 % Senior Subordinated Notes due 2016 discussed below.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S14	Interest on our senior notes is payable semi-annually.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S15	The notes are unsecured and unsubordinated obligations and rank equally with all of our other existing and future unsecured and unsubordinated obligations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S16	We may redeem some or all of our senior notes at any time before their maturity at a redemption price based on a make-whole amount plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of redemption.
912750_13_ITEM8_P102_S17	The indentures governing our senior notes contain covenants that may limit our ability to, among other things:
912750_13_ITEM8_P103_S0	enter into merger or consolidation transactions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P103_S1	The indentures also provide that if any of our subsidiaries guarantee any of our indebtedness at any time in the future, then we will cause our senior notes to be equally and ratably guaranteed by that subsidiary.
912750_13_ITEM8_P103_S2	At December 31, 2012, we were in compliance with all of our debt covenants.

912750_13_ITEM8_P110_S0	At December 31, the components of our deferred tax asset and deferred tax liability were as follows:
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S0	We evaluate our cash flows and capital projects for domestic and international operations annually.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S1	Our foreign operations generated excess cash flow for the first time in 2012, and we estimate them to be cash flow neutral or generating excess cash flow in future years.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S2	In the fourth quarter 2012, we restructured our foreign operations as a result of deciding to invest excess international cash into our domestic operations for the next few years, and consequently, the permanent international reinvestment tax assertion is no longer applicable.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S3	As a result, we recorded $521 million of U.S. deferred taxes for our inception-to-December 31, 2012 foreign earnings, which had not been recorded previously and will record U.S. taxes on future international earnings annually.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S4	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011, we had gross net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards of approximately $0.5 billion and $2.0 billion for federal income tax and $1.6 billion and $1.0 billion for state income tax purposes, respectively, which may be used in future years to offset taxable income.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S5	NOL carryforwards of $223 million are subject to annual limitations due to stock ownership changes.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S6	We currently estimate that we will not be able to utilize $126 million of our various gross state NOLs because we do not have sufficient estimated future taxable income in the appropriate jurisdictions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S7	To the extent not utilized, the federal NOL carryforwards will begin to expire during the years 2019 through 2031.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S8	As of December 31, 2012 and 2011, we had gross NOL carryforwards for international income tax purposes of approximately $17 million and $48 million, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S9	During the year ended December 31, 2012, we utilized international NOLs of $31 million, which were generated in 2011.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S10	In addition, as of December 31, 2012 and 2011, we had $17 million of international NOLs, which we currently estimate that we will not be able to utilize because we do not have sufficient estimated future taxable income in the appropriate jurisdictions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P111_S11	As a result, valuation allowances were established for these items in 2005 and 2006.
912750_13_ITEM8_P112_S0	Utilization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon generating sufficient future taxable income in the appropriate jurisdictions within the carryforward period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P113_S0	Estimates of future taxable income can be significantly affected by changes in oil, gas and NGL prices; estimates of the timing and amount of future production; and estimates of future operating and capital costs.
912750_13_ITEM8_P113_S1	Therefore, no certainty exists that we will be able to fully utilize our existing deferred tax assets.

912750_13_ITEM8_P115_S0	Stock-Based Compensation: All stock-based compensation equity awards to employees and non-employee directors are currently granted under the 2011 Omnibus Stock Plan (our 2011 Plan).
912750_13_ITEM8_P115_S1	The fair value of grants is determined utilizing the Black-Scholes option-pricing model for stock options and a lattice-based model for our performance and market-based restricted stock and restricted stock units.
912750_13_ITEM8_P115_S2	In February 2011, we also granted cash-settled restricted stock units to employees.
912750_13_ITEM8_P115_S3	These awards were not issued under any of our plans as they will be settled in cash upon vesting and are accounted for as liability awards.

912750_13_ITEM8_P117_S0	Our stock-based compensation consisted of the following for the years ended December 31: The excess tax benefit realized from stock options exercised is recognized as a credit to additional paid-in capital and is calculated as the amount by which the tax deduction we receive exceeds the deferred tax asset associated with recorded stock-based compensation expense.
912750_13_ITEM8_P117_S1	We did not realize an excess tax benefit from stock-based compensation for 2012, 2011 or 2010 because we did not have sufficient taxable income to fully realize the deduction.

912750_13_ITEM8_P123_S0	Pursuant to our employee stock purchase plan, for each six-month period beginning on January 1 or July 1 during the term of the plan, each eligible employee has the opportunity to purchase our common stock for a purchase price equal to 85% of the lesser of the fair market value of our common stock on the first day of the period or the last day of the period.

912750_13_ITEM8_P123_S2	Employees of our foreign subsidiaries are not eligible to participate in the plan.

912750_13_ITEM8_P127_S2	Our net periodic benefit cost was approximately $2 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 and approximately $1 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
912750_13_ITEM8_P127_S3	The expected future benefit payments under our post-retirement medical plan for the next ten years are as follows (in millions):
912750_13_ITEM8_P128_S0	Annual Cash Incentive Compensation Plan During 2010, our Board of Directors, with the recommendation of the Compensation Management Development Committee, approved a new annual cash incentive compensation plan for all employees (the 2011 Annual Incentive Plan).
912750_13_ITEM8_P129_S0	Under the 2011 Annual Incentive Plan, the Compensation Management Development Committee determines the annual award pool for all employees based upon a number of factors including the Company s performance against stated performance goals and in comparison with peer companies in our industry.
912750_13_ITEM8_P129_S1	All employees are eligible if employed on October 1 and December 31 of the performance period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P129_S2	Beginning with the year ended December 31, 2010, our annual cash incentive compensation is paid in a single payment to employees during the first quarter after the end of the performance period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P129_S3	Total incentive compensation expense for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010 was $41 million, $39 million and $36 million, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S0	401(k) and Deferred Compensation Plans We sponsor a 401(k) profit sharing plan under Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S1	This plan covers all of our employees, excluding those of our foreign subsidiaries.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S2	We match $1.00 for each $1.00 of employee deferral, with our contribution not to exceed 8% of an employee s salary, subject to limitations imposed by the IRS.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S3	We also sponsor a highly compensated employee deferred compensation plan.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S4	This non-qualified plan allows an eligible employee to defer a portion of his or her salary or bonus on an annual basis.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S5	We match $1.00 for each $1.00 of employee deferral, with our contribution not to exceed 8% of an employee s salary, subject to limitations imposed by the plan.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S6	Our contribution with respect to each participant in the deferred compensation plan is reduced by the amount of contribution made by us to our 401(k) plan for that participant.
912750_13_ITEM8_P130_S7	Our combined contributions to these two plans for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010 totaled $10 million, $8 million and $6 million, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P131_S0	Commitments and Contingencies: We have various commitments for firm transportation, operating lease agreements for office space and other agreements.
912750_13_ITEM8_P131_S1	As of December 31, 2012, future minimum payments under these non-cancelable agreements are as follows: Firm transportation is comprised of various agreements with third parties for oil and gas gathering and transportation.
912750_13_ITEM8_P131_S2	Rent expense with respect to our lease commitments for office space for the years ended December 31, 2012, 2011 and 2010 was $19 million, $16 million and $11 million, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P132_S0	Our other agreements primarily consist of platform construction and drilling rigs.
912750_13_ITEM8_P132_S1	Payments under these contracts are accounted for as capital additions to our oil and gas properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P132_S2	As is common in the oil and gas industry, we have various contractual commitments pertaining to exploration, development and production activities, which are not included in the table above.
912750_13_ITEM8_P132_S3	We have work-related commitments for, among other things, drilling wells, obtaining and processing seismic data, transportation of our production and fulfilling other related commitments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P132_S4	At December 31, 2012, these work-related commitments totaled $132 million, all of which were attributable to our international businesses.
912750_13_ITEM8_P133_S0	We have various oil and gas production volume delivery commitments that are related to our domestic operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P133_S1	As of December 31, 2012, our delivery commitments through 2024 were as follows:
912750_13_ITEM8_P134_S0	(1) Our oil delivery commitments include a particular commitment with a Salt Lake City, Utah refiner.
912750_13_ITEM8_P134_S1	This delivery commitment will begin upon the refiner completing the expansion of their facility, which is expected in late 2014 or early 2015.
912750_13_ITEM8_P134_S2	Our delivery commitment is to deliver approximately 20,000 barrels of oil per day over a 10-year period.
912750_13_ITEM8_P134_S3	This delivery commitment represents approximately 50% of our committed oil volumes for each of the years 2015 through 2019, increases to 77% in 2020, and is 100% of our commitment through 2024.
912750_13_ITEM8_P135_S0	Given the size of our proved natural gas and oil reserves and production capacity in the respective divisions, we currently believe that we have sufficient reserves and production to fulfill these commitments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P135_S1	However, in the event that we are unable to meet our crude oil volume delivery commitments, we would incur deficiency fees ranging from $2.55 to $6.50 per barrel.
912750_13_ITEM8_P136_S0	Litigation We have been named as a defendant in a number of lawsuits and are involved in various other disputes, all arising in the ordinary course of our business, such as (a) claims from royalty owners for disputed royalty payments, (b) commercial disputes, (c) personal injury claims and (d) property damage claims.
912750_13_ITEM8_P136_S1	Although the outcome of these lawsuits and disputes cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not expect these matters to have a material adverse effect on our financial position, cash flows or results of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P136_S2	Other on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_13_ITEM8_P137_S0	Segment Information: While we only have operations in the oil and gas exploration and production industry, we are organizationally structured along geographic operating segments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P137_S1	Our current operating segments are the United States, Malaysia, China and Other International.
912750_13_ITEM8_P137_S2	The accounting policies of each of our operating segments are the same as those described in Note 1, Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies.

912750_13_ITEM8_P140_S0	Related Party Transaction: Kevin M. Robinson, our Vice President Asia, and Susan G. Riggs, our Treasurer, are minority owners of Huffco International L.L.C. (Huffco).
912750_13_ITEM8_P141_S0	In May 1997, before Mr. Robinson and Ms. Riggs joined us, we acquired from Huffco an entity now known as Newfield China, LDC, the owner of a 12% interest in a three field unit located on Blocks 04/36 and 05/36 in Bohai Bay, offshore China.
912750_13_ITEM8_P141_S1	Huffco retained preferred shares of Newfield China that provide for an aggregate dividend equal to 10% of the excess of proceeds received by Newfield China from the sale of oil, gas and other minerals over all costs incurred with respect to exploration and production in Block 05/36, plus the cash purchase price we paid Huffco for Newfield China ($6 million).
912750_13_ITEM8_P141_S2	During 2012, 2011 and 2010, Newfield China paid $7 million, $5 million and $4 million, respectively, of dividends to Huffco on the preferred shares of Newfield China.
912750_13_ITEM8_P141_S3	Based on our estimate of the net present value of the proved reserves associated with Block 05/36, the indirect interest (through Huffco) in Newfield China s preferred shares held by Mr. Robinson and Ms. Riggs had a net present value of approximately $94,000 and $235,000, respectively at December 31, 2012.

912750_13_ITEM8_P144_S0	(2) Income (loss) from operations for the fourth quarter of 2012 includes a full cost ceiling test writedown of $1.5 billion.

912750_13_ITEM8_P149_S0	Reserves Users of this information should be aware that the process of estimating quantities of proved and proved developed oil and gas reserves is very complex, requiring significant subjective decisions in the evaluation of all available geological, engineering and economic data for each reservoir.
912750_13_ITEM8_P149_S1	The data for a given reservoir also may change substantially over time as a result of numerous factors, including additional development activity, evolving production history and continual reassessment of the viability of production under varying economic conditions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P149_S2	Consequently, material revisions to existing reserve estimates may occur from time to time.
912750_13_ITEM8_P150_S0	All reserve information in this report is based on estimates prepared by our petroleum engineering staff and is the responsibility of management.
912750_13_ITEM8_P150_S1	The preparation of our oil and gas reserves estimates is completed in accordance with our prescribed internal control procedures, which include verification of data input into our reserves forecasting and economics evaluation software, as well as multi-discipline management reviews.
912750_13_ITEM8_P150_S2	The technical employee responsible for overseeing the preparation of the reserves estimates has a Bachelor of Science in Petroleum Engineering, with more than 30 years of experience (including 20 years of experience in reserve estimation).
912750_13_ITEM8_P150_S3	For additional information regarding our reserves estimation process, please see Items 1 and 2, Business and Properties Reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S0	NEWFIELD EXPLORATION COMPANY SUPPLEMENTARY FINANCIAL INFORMATION SUPPLEMENTARY OIL AND GAS DISCLOSURES UNAUDITED (Continued) Reserves Activity Overview.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S1	The following is a discussion of our proved reserves and reserve additions and revisions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S2	Our proved natural gas reserves at year-end 2012 were 1.8 Tcf compared to 2.3 Tcf and 2.5 Tcf at year-end 2011 and 2010, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S3	Our proved crude oil and condensate reserves at year-end 2012 were 237 MMBbls compared to 247 MMBbls and 198 MMBbls at year-end 2011 and 2010, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S4	Our proved NGL reserves at year-end 2012 were 37 MMBbls compared to 16 MMBbls and 6 MMBbls at year-end 2011 and 2010, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S5	Oil, condensate and NGLs comprised about 48%, 40% and 33% of our proved reserves at year-end 2012, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S6	During 2012, our proved reserves decreased 30 Bcfe as a result of additions (extensions, discoveries, improved recovery and purchases of reserves in place) being more than offset by revisions of previous estimates, mostly due to price as described below.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S7	We expect the majority of future reserve growth to be associated with infill drilling, extensions of current fields and new discoveries, as well as improved recovery operations and purchases of proved properties.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S8	The success of these operations will directly impact reserve additions or revisions in the future.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S9	We added 512 Bcfe of proved reserves through discoveries, extensions and other additions, and 4 Bcfe through purchases.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S10	Drilling additions related to our resource plays in the Mid-Continent, Rocky Mountains and South Texas constituted 92% of our additions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S11	Of the drilling additions, 362 Bcfe or 60 MMBOE were proved undeveloped additions and 13 MMBOE were proved developed oil and NGL reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S12	We added 909 Bcfe of proved reserves during 2011.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S13	Approximately 857 Bcfe of the additions resulted from discoveries, extensions and other additions, and 52 Bcfe related to purchases.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S14	Drilling additions related primarily to activities in our resource plays in the Mid-Continent and Rocky Mountains.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S15	Of the drilling additions, 430 Bcfe or 72 MMBOE were proved undeveloped additions in the Rocky Mountains, associated primarily with the Williston basin and the Greater Monument Butte Unit.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S16	In addition, 16 MMBbls of proved developed oil reserves were added during 2011.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S17	While total proved reserve revisions in 2012 were a negative 546 Bcfe or 14% of the beginning of year proved reserves, they included a negative price revision of 616 Bcfe primarily related to our onshore natural gas plays.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S18	The largest area affected by lower natural gas prices was the Woodford Shale.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S19	Price revisions there were primarily to proved undeveloped reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S20	In mature plays, dominated by infill drilling and where reserve growth cannot be classified as an extension or discovery, the change in reserves is captured as a revision.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S21	In 2012, our revisions associated with the development of existing fields were a positive 70 Bcfe.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S22	Our total proved reserve revisions in 2011 were 288 Bcfe.
912750_13_ITEM8_P151_S23	Price-related and other revisions were negligible.
912750_13_ITEM8_P152_S0	higher margin oil drilling and the locations associated with these reserves moved outside of a five-year development horizon.
912750_13_ITEM8_P152_S1	Negative performance revisions in 2011 were 198 Bcfe, which included (i) well performance as efforts to extend the Green River section northwest of the Greater Monument Butte Unit encountered higher than expected natural gas production, (ii) the timing of waterflood response recognition in the Greater Monument Butte Unit, (iii) wellbore failures in gas reservoirs along the Gulf Coast and (iv) offset well interference in older vertical natural gas wells in the Mid-Continent region, which were adversely impacted by new horizontal well completions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P152_S2	In 2012, we sold 180 Bcfe of proved reserves associated with non-strategic assets.
912750_13_ITEM8_P152_S3	In 2011, we sold 122 Bcfe of proved reserves associated with non-strategic assets.
912750_13_ITEM8_P152_S4	In 2010, sales of reserves were negligible.
912750_13_ITEM8_P152_S5	The following table sets forth our total net proved reserves and our total net proved developed and undeveloped reserves as of December 31, 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012 and the changes in our total net proved reserves during the three-year period ended December 31, 2012:
912750_13_ITEM8_P153_S0	(1) All of our reserves in Malaysia and China are associated with production sharing contracts and are calculated using the economic interest method.
912750_13_ITEM8_P154_S0	(1) All of our reserves in Malaysia and China are associated with production sharing contracts and are calculated using the economic interest method.
912750_13_ITEM8_P155_S0	The following information was developed utilizing procedures prescribed by FASB Accounting Standards Codification Topic 932, Extractive Industries Oil and Gas (Topic 932).
912750_13_ITEM8_P155_S1	The information is based on estimates prepared by our petroleum engineering staff.
912750_13_ITEM8_P155_S2	The standardized measure of discounted future net cash flows should not be viewed as representative of the current value of our proved oil and gas reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P155_S3	It and the other information contained in the following tables may be useful for certain comparative purposes, but should not be solely relied upon in evaluating us or our performance.
912750_13_ITEM8_P156_S0	In reviewing the information that follows, we believe that the following factors should be taken into account:
912750_13_ITEM8_P157_S0	future net revenues may be subject to different income tax rates.
912750_13_ITEM8_P158_S0	Under the standardized measure, future cash inflows were estimated by applying the prices used in estimating our proved oil and gas reserves to the year-end quantities of those reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P159_S0	Future cash inflows do not reflect the impact of open hedge positions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P159_S1	See Note 4, Derivative Financial Instruments.
912750_13_ITEM8_P160_S0	Future cash inflows were reduced by estimated future development, abandonment and production costs based on year-end costs in order to arrive at net cash flows before tax.
912750_13_ITEM8_P160_S1	Future income tax expense has been computed by applying year-end statutory tax rates to aggregate future pre-tax net cash flows reduced by the tax basis of the properties involved and tax carryforwards.
912750_13_ITEM8_P160_S2	The standardized measure is derived from using a discount rate of 10% a year to reflect the timing of future net cash flows relating to proved oil and gas reserves.
912750_13_ITEM8_P161_S0	In general, management does not rely on the following information in making investment and operating decisions.
912750_13_ITEM8_P161_S1	Such decisions are based upon a wide range of factors, including estimates of probable as well as proved reserves and varying price and cost assumptions considered more representative of a range of possible outcomes.
