912750_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The table below summarizes our significant contractual obligations due by year as of December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	_________________ (1) Excludes assets and liabilities associated with our derivative contracts, which are dependent on the commodity price at the time of the contract settlement.
912750_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	For a discussion regarding our derivative contracts, see Note 4 , "Derivative Financial Instruments," to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report.
912750_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	(2) Includes agreements for office space, drilling rigs and other equipment, as well as certain service contracts.
912750_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	The majority of these obligations are related to contracts for office space and drilling rigs and are included at the gross contractual value.
912750_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	Due to our various working interests where the drilling rig contracts will be utilized, it is not feasible to estimate a net contractual obligation.
912750_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	Net payments under these contracts are accounted for as capital additions to our oil and gas properties and could be less than the gross obligation disclosed.
912750_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	We have various oil and gas production volume delivery commitments that are related to our Uinta Basin production.
912750_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	Given the decline in oil and natural gas prices and the related impact on our 2016 planned capital investments, as well as the potential impact on development plans in future years, we could fail to deliver the minimum production required under these commitments.
912750_16_ITEM7_P78_S2	In the event that we are unable to meet our crude oil volume delivery commitments, we incur deficiency fees ranging from $3.50 to $6.50 per barrel.
912750_16_ITEM7_P78_S3	Based on forecasted production levels for 2016, we are projected to incur approximately $15 million in deficiency fees related to these delivery commitments.
912750_16_ITEM7_P78_S4	See Items 1 and 2, Business and Properties for a description of our production and proved reserves.
912750_16_ITEM7_P78_S5	As of December 31, 2015 , our delivery commitments through 2025 were as follows:
912750_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	_________________ (1) Our oil delivery commitments are with two Salt Lake City, Utah refiners and relate to our Uinta Basin production.
912750_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	One delivery commitment is for approximately 18,000 barrels of oil per day through 2020.
912750_16_ITEM7_P79_S2	The second commitment is for 15,000 barrels of oil per day in January 2016, increasing to 20,000 barrels of oil per day by the end of the third quarter 2016, and continues at that level through August 2025.
912750_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	Most of our properties are operated through joint ventures under joint operating or similar agreements.
912750_16_ITEM7_P80_S1	Typically, the operator under a joint operating agreement enters into contracts, such as drilling contracts, for the benefit of all joint venture partners.
912750_16_ITEM7_P80_S2	Through the joint operating agreement, the non-operators reimburse, and in some cases advance, the funds necessary to meet the contractual obligations entered into by the operator.
912750_16_ITEM7_P80_S3	These obligations are typically shared on a working interest basis.
912750_16_ITEM7_P81_S0	operator does not satisfy its share of the contractual obligations.
912750_16_ITEM7_P81_S1	Occasionally, the operator is permitted by the joint operating agreement to enter into lease obligations and other contractual commitments that are then passed on to the non-operating joint interest owners as lease operating expenses, frequently without any identification as to the long-term nature of any commitments underlying such expenses.
912750_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	We use derivative contracts to manage the variability in cash flows caused by commodity price fluctuations associated with our anticipated future oil and gas production for the next 24 to 36 months.
912750_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	As of December 31, 2015 , we had no outstanding derivative contracts related to our NGL production.
912750_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	We do not use derivative instruments for trading purposes.
912750_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	For a further discussion of our derivative activities, see "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Commodity Derivative Activities" below and "Oil, Natural Gas and NGL Prices" in Item 7A of this report.
912750_16_ITEM7_P83_S1	See the discussion and tables in Note 4 , "Derivative Financial Instruments," and Note 5 , "Fair Value Measurements," to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report for additional information regarding the accounting applicable to our oil and gas derivative contracts, a listing of open contracts and the estimated fair market value of those contracts as of December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	Between January 1, 2016 and February 19, 2016 , we did not enter into additional derivative contracts.
912750_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	We do not currently utilize any off-balance sheet arrangements with unconsolidated entities to enhance liquidity and capital resource positions, or for any other purpose.
912750_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	The discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
912750_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	The preparation of our financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect our reported results of operations and the amount of reported assets, liabilities and proved oil and gas reserves.
912750_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	Some accounting policies involve judgments and uncertainties to such an extent that there is reasonable likelihood that materially different amounts could have been reported under different conditions or if different assumptions had been used.
912750_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	We evaluate our estimates and assumptions on a regular basis.
912750_16_ITEM7_P88_S1	We base our estimates on historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for our judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
912750_16_ITEM7_P88_S2	Actual results may differ from these estimates and assumptions used in preparation of our financial statements.
912750_16_ITEM7_P88_S3	See Note 1 , Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report for a full description of the critical accounting policies and estimates below, as well as other accounting policies and estimates we make.
912750_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	Below are the most significant policies we apply in preparing our financial statements, some of which are subject to alternative treatments under generally accepted accounting principles.
912750_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	We also describe the most significant estimates and assumptions we make in applying these policies.
912750_16_ITEM7_P89_S2	We discussed the development, selection and disclosure of each of these with the Audit Committee of our Board of Directors.
912750_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	Two generally accepted accounting methods are available for accounting for oil and gas producing activities successful efforts and full cost.
912750_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	The most significant differences between these methods are the treatment of exploration costs and the manner in which the carrying values of oil and gas properties are amortized and evaluated for impairment.
912750_16_ITEM7_P90_S2	The successful efforts method requires unsuccessful exploration costs to be expensed, while these costs are capitalized under the full cost method.
912750_16_ITEM7_P90_S3	Both methods provide for the periodic amortization of capitalized costs based on proved reserve quantities.
912750_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	Impairment of oil and gas properties under the successful efforts method is a two-step test that compares the carrying value of the properties to the undiscounted cash flows to assess for impairment.
912750_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	If required, the impairment is the difference between the carrying value of individual oil and gas properties and their estimated fair value using forward-looking prices.
912750_16_ITEM7_P91_S2	Impairment under the full cost method requires an evaluation of the after-tax carrying value of oil and gas properties included in a cost center against the after-tax net present value of future cash flows from the related proved reserves, using SEC pricing, costs in effect at year-end and a 10% discount rate.
912750_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	We use the full cost method of accounting for our oil and gas activities.
912750_16_ITEM7_P92_S1	Our financial position and results of operations would have been significantly different had we used the successful efforts method.
912750_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	Proved Oil, Natural Gas and NGL Reserves.
912750_16_ITEM7_P93_S1	Our engineering estimates of proved oil, natural gas and NGL reserves directly impact financial accounting estimates, including DD A expense and the full cost ceiling limitation.
912750_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	gas and NGL reserves are the estimated quantities of oil, natural gas and NGL reserves that geological and engineering data demonstrates with reasonable certainty to be recoverable in future years from known reservoirs based on SEC pricing and under period-end economic and operating conditions.
912750_16_ITEM7_P94_S1	The process of estimating quantities of proved reserves is very complex, requiring significant subjective decisions in the evaluation of all geological, engineering and economic data for each reservoir.
912750_16_ITEM7_P94_S2	The data for a given reservoir may change substantially over time as a result of numerous factors, including development activity, evolving production history and continual reassessment of the viability of production under varying economic conditions.
912750_16_ITEM7_P94_S3	Changes in commodity prices, operating costs and expected performance from a given reservoir will result in future revisions to our estimated proved reserves quantities.
912750_16_ITEM7_P94_S4	All reserve information in this report is based on estimates prepared by our petroleum engineering staff.
912750_16_ITEM7_P95_S0	Under the full cost method, all costs incurred in the acquisition, exploration and development of oil and gas properties, including salaries, benefits, interest and other internal costs directly attributable to these activities, are capitalized into country-based cost centers .
912750_16_ITEM7_P95_S1	Proceeds from the sale of oil and gas properties are applied as a reduction of the costs in the applicable cost center unless the reduction would significantly alter the relationship between capitalized costs and proved reserves, in which case a gain or loss is recognized.
912750_16_ITEM7_P95_S2	Future development and abandonment costs are added, and unevaluated costs are withheld from the net costs capitalized in cost centers to represent a full cost pool, which is amortized and assessed for impairment.
912750_16_ITEM7_P96_S0	Future development costs include expected costs to obtain access to proved reserves such as drilling costs and the installation of production equipment.
912750_16_ITEM7_P96_S1	Future abandonment costs include costs to dismantle and relocate or dispose of our gathering systems, production platforms and related structures and restoration costs of land and seabed.
912750_16_ITEM7_P96_S2	We estimate these costs for each of our properties based upon their geographic location, type of production structure, water depth, reservoir depth and characteristics, market demand for equipment, currently available procedures and information from our engineering consultants.
912750_16_ITEM7_P96_S3	Because these costs typically extend many years into the future, estimation is difficult and requires judgments that are subject to revisions based upon numerous factors, including changing technology and the political and regulatory environment.
912750_16_ITEM7_P97_S0	We review our assumptions and estimates of future development and abandonment costs annually, or more frequently if circumstances change.
912750_16_ITEM7_P98_S0	The accounting guidance for future abandonment costs requires that a liability and corresponding long-lived asset for the discounted fair value of an asset retirement obligation be recorded in the period in which it is incurred.
912750_16_ITEM7_P98_S1	The liability is increased to its present value each period, and the capitalized cost is depreciated over the useful life of the related asset.
912750_16_ITEM7_P99_S0	Holding all other factors constant, if our estimate of future development and abandonment costs is revised upward, earnings would decrease due to higher DD A expense.
912750_16_ITEM7_P99_S1	Likewise, if these estimates are revised downward, earnings would increase due to lower DD A expense.
912750_16_ITEM7_P99_S2	To change our diluted earnings per share by $0.01 for the year ended December 31, 2015 , our domestic DD A rate would need to change by $0.17 per BOE, which would require a change in estimate of our domestic future development and abandonment costs of approximately 4%, or $87 million.
912750_16_ITEM7_P99_S3	Our China DD A rate would need to change by $1.99 per BOE, which would require a change in estimate of our China future development and abandonment costs of approximately 499%, or $23 million.
912750_16_ITEM7_P100_S0	Costs associated with unevaluated properties are excluded from our amortization base until we have evaluated the properties or impairment is indicated.
912750_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	The costs associated with unevaluated leasehold acreage and related seismic data, wells currently drilling and capitalized interest are initially excluded from our amortization base.
912750_16_ITEM7_P100_S2	Leasehold costs are either transferred to our amortization base with the costs of drilling a well on the lease or are assessed at least annually for possible impairment or reduction in value.
912750_16_ITEM7_P100_S3	Leasehold costs are transferred to our amortization base to the extent a reduction in value has occurred, or a charge is made against earnings if the costs were incurred in a country for which a reserve base has not been established.
912750_16_ITEM7_P100_S4	Currently, there are no unevaluated properties for our China business.
912750_16_ITEM7_P101_S0	Our decision to withhold costs from amortization and the timing of the transfer of those costs into the amortization base involves a significant amount of judgment and may be subject to changes over time based on several factors, including our drilling plans, availability of capital, project economics and drilling results from adjacent acreage.
912750_16_ITEM7_P101_S1	At December 31, 2015 , we had a total of $780 million of costs excluded from the respective full cost pools, all of which related to our domestic full cost pool.
912750_16_ITEM7_P101_S2	Inclusion of some or all of these costs in our domestic full cost pool, without adding any associated reserves, would have resulted in additional ceiling test writedowns.
912750_16_ITEM7_P102_S0	The full cost pool for each country is amortized using a unit-of-production method based on the cost center's proved oil, natural gas and NGL reserves.
912750_16_ITEM7_P102_S1	Estimated proved reserves are a significant component of the calculation of DD A expense, and revisions in such estimates may alter the rate of future expense.
912750_16_ITEM7_P103_S0	all other factors constant, if reserves are revised upward, earnings would increase due to lower depletion expense.
912750_16_ITEM7_P103_S1	Likewise, if reserves are revised downward, earnings would decrease due to higher depletion expense or due to a ceiling test writedown.
912750_16_ITEM7_P103_S2	To change our diluted earnings per share for continuing operations by $0.01 for the year ended December 31, 2015 , our domestic DD A rate would need to change by $0.17 per BOE, which would require a change in the estimate of our domestic proved reserves of approximately 2%, or 8 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM7_P103_S3	Our China DD A rate would need to change by $1.99 per BOE, which would require a change in the estimate of our China proved reserves of approximately 8%, or 1 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM7_P104_S0	Under the full cost method, we are subject to quarterly calculations of a ceiling or limitation on the amount of oil and gas property costs that can be capitalized on our balance sheet.
912750_16_ITEM7_P104_S1	The discounted present value of our proved reserves is a major component of the ceiling calculation and represents the component that requires the most subjective judgments.
912750_16_ITEM7_P105_S0	The ceiling value of oil, natural gas and NGL reserves is calculated based on SEC pricing and costs in effect as of the last day of the quarter.
912750_16_ITEM7_P105_S1	Once recorded, a ceiling test writedown is not reversible at a later date even if oil and gas prices increase.
912750_16_ITEM7_P106_S0	Holding all other factors constant, it is likely that we will experience a ceiling test writedown in both the U.S. and China in the first quarter of 2016.
912750_16_ITEM7_P107_S0	It is difficult to predict with reasonable certainty the amount of expected future impairments given the many factors impacting the ceiling test calculation including, but not limited to, future pricing, operating and development costs, upward or downward reserve revisions, reserve adds and tax attributes.
912750_16_ITEM7_P107_S1	Subject to these numerous factors and inherent limitations, we believe that impairments in the first quarter of 2016 could exceed $500 million .
912750_16_ITEM7_P108_S0	Allocation of Purchase Price in Business Combinations.
912750_16_ITEM7_P108_S1	We monitor and screen for potential acquisitions of oil and gas properties.
912750_16_ITEM7_P109_S0	The purchase price in an acquisition is allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their relative fair values as of the acquisition date, which may occur many months after the announcement date.
912750_16_ITEM7_P109_S1	Therefore, while the consideration to be paid may be fixed, the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is subject to change during the period between the announcement date and the acquisition date.
912750_16_ITEM7_P110_S0	Our most significant estimates in our allocation typically relate to the value assigned to future recoverable oil and natural gas reserves and unproved properties.
912750_16_ITEM7_P110_S1	To the extent the consideration paid exceeds the fair value of the net assets acquired, we are required to record the excess as goodwill.
912750_16_ITEM7_P110_S2	As the allocation of the purchase price is subject to significant estimates and subjective judgments, the accuracy of this assessment is inherently uncertain.
912750_16_ITEM7_P111_S0	The value allocated to recoverable oil and natural gas reserves and unproved properties is subject to the cost center ceiling as described under Full Cost Ceiling above.
912750_16_ITEM7_P112_S0	The accounting standard for business combinations establishes how a purchaser recognizes and measures in its financial statements the identifiable assets acquired, the liabilities assumed, and any non-controlling interest in the acquiree.
912750_16_ITEM7_P112_S1	The standard also sets forth guidance related to the recognition, measurement and disclosure related to goodwill acquired in a business combination or gains associated with a bargain purchase transaction.
912750_16_ITEM7_P113_S0	Under accounting rules, we may elect to designate certain derivative contracts that qualify for hedge accounting as cash flow hedges against the price that we will receive for our future oil and gas production.
912750_16_ITEM7_P113_S1	However, we do not designate any of our derivative contracts as accounting hedges.
912750_16_ITEM7_P113_S2	Because derivative contracts not designated for hedge accounting are accounted for on a mark-to-market basis, we have in the past experienced, and are likely in the future to experience non-cash volatility in our reported earnings during periods of commodity price volatility.
912750_16_ITEM7_P114_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we had net derivative assets of $367 million , of which 71%, based on total contracted volumes, was measured based upon a modified Black-Scholes valuation model and, as such, is classified as a Level 3 fair value measurement.
912750_16_ITEM7_P114_S1	The value of these contracts at their respective settlement dates could be significantly different than the fair value as of December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM7_P115_S0	We periodically validate our valuations using independent third-party quotations.
912750_16_ITEM7_P115_S1	For further discussion of our derivative instruments and activities, see "Oil, Natural Gas and NGL Prices," in Item 7A of this report.
912750_16_ITEM7_P115_S2	Also see Note 4 , "Derivative Financial Instruments," and Note 5 , "Fair Value Measurements," to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report for additional information regarding the accounting applicable to our oil and gas derivative contracts, a listing of open contracts and the estimated fair market value of those contracts as of December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM7_P116_S0	We apply a fair value-based method of accounting for stock-based compensation, which requires recognition in the financial statements of the cost of services received in exchange for awards of equity instruments based on the grant date fair value of those awards.
912750_16_ITEM7_P116_S1	For equity awards, compensation expense is based on the fair value on the grant or modification date and is recognized in our financial statements over the vesting period.
912750_16_ITEM7_P116_S2	We utilize the Black-Scholes option-pricing model to measure the fair value of stock options and a Monte Carlo lattice-based model for our performance and market-based restricted stock and restricted stock units.
912750_16_ITEM7_P116_S3	We also have cash-settled restricted stock units that are accounted for under the liability method, which requires us to recognize the fair value of each award based on the underlying share price at the end of each period.
912750_16_ITEM7_P116_S4	See Note 14 , Stock-Based Compensation, to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report for a full discussion of our stock-based compensation.
912750_16_ITEM7_P117_S0	The amount of income taxes recorded by the Company requires significant judgment by management and is reviewed and adjusted routinely based on changes in facts and circumstances.
912750_16_ITEM7_P118_S0	We use the liability method of accounting for income taxes.
912750_16_ITEM7_P118_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined by applying tax regulations existing at the end of a reporting period to the cumulative temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their reported amounts in our financial statements.
912750_16_ITEM7_P118_S2	Utilization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon generating sufficient future taxable income in the appropriate jurisdictions within the carryforward period.
912750_16_ITEM7_P119_S0	Estimates of future taxable income can be significantly affected by changes in oil, gas and NGL prices; estimates of the timing and amount of future production; and estimates of future operating and capital costs.
912750_16_ITEM7_P119_S1	Therefore, no certainty exists that we will be able to fully utilize deferred tax assets.
912750_16_ITEM7_P120_S0	We assess the available positive and negative evidence to estimate if sufficient taxable income will be generated to utilize deferred tax assets.
912750_16_ITEM7_P121_S0	A valuation allowance is established to reduce deferred tax assets if it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the related deferred tax benefits will not be realized.
912750_16_ITEM7_P121_S1	Changes in judgment regarding future realizability of deferred tax assets may result in the reversal of all or a portion of the valuation allowance.
912750_16_ITEM7_P121_S2	In the period that determination is made, our net income will benefit from a lower effective tax rate.
912750_16_ITEM7_P121_S3	See Note 7 , Income Taxes, to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report for a full discussion of income taxes.
912750_16_ITEM7_P122_S0	See Note 1, Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report for a discussion of new accounting requirements.
912750_16_ITEM7_P123_S0	Exploration, development, production and the sale of oil, gas and NGLs are subject to extensive federal, state, provincial, tribal, local and international regulations.
912750_16_ITEM7_P123_S1	An overview of these regulations is set forth in Items 1 and 2, Business and Properties Regulation.
912750_16_ITEM7_P123_S2	We believe we are in substantial compliance with currently applicable laws and regulations and that continued substantial compliance with existing requirements will not have a material adverse effect on our financial position, cash flows or results of operations.
912750_16_ITEM7_P123_S3	However, current regulatory requirements may change, currently unforeseen environmental incidents may occur or past non-compliance with environmental laws or regulations may be discovered.
912750_16_ITEM7_P123_S4	Please see the discussion under the caption We are subject to complex laws and regulatory actions that can affect the cost, manner, feasibility or timing of doing business," in Item 1A of this report.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are exposed to market risk from changes in oil, natural gas and NGL prices, interest rates and foreign currency exchange rates as discussed below.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our decision on the quantity and price at which we choose to enter into derivative contracts is based in part on our view of current and future market conditions.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P1_S1	While the use of derivative contracts can limit or reduce the downside risk of adverse price movements, their use also may limit future benefits from favorable price movements.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P1_S2	In addition, the use of derivative contracts may involve basis risk.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	All of our derivative transactions have been carried out in the over-the-counter market.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The use of derivative contracts also involves the risk that the counterparties, which generally are financial institutions, will be unable to meet the financial terms of such transactions.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Our derivative contracts are with multiple counterparties to minimize our exposure to any individual counterparty.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P3_S2	At December 31, 2015 , 10 of our 15 counterparties accounted for approximately 85% of our contracted volumes with the largest counterparty accounting for approximately 15% .
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Of our expected 2016 crude oil production, 16,280 MBbls are partially protected against price volatility through the use of collars and swaps, all of which have associated sold puts.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S1	The sold puts limit our downward price protection below the weighted average price of our sold puts of $74.47 per barrel.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S2	If the market price remains below $74.47 per barrel, we receive the market price for our associated production plus the difference between our sold puts and the associated floors or fixed-price swaps, which averages $15.52 per barrel.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S3	For 6,242 MBbls of our 2016 volumes, we have locked in an average minimum premium of $13.62 over the market price through the use of purchased calls.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S4	The weighted average strike price of the purchased calls approximates the weighted average strike price of the sold puts, thereby effectively locking in the value.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S5	Of our expected 2017 crude oil production, 6,548 MBbls are partially protected against price volatility through the use of collars and swaps, all of which have associated sold puts.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S6	The sold puts limit our downward price protection below the weighted average price of our sold puts of $73.83 per barrel.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P4_S7	If the market price remains below $73.83 per barrel, we receive the market price for our associated production plus the difference between our sold puts and the associated floors or fixed-price swaps, which averages $15.06 per barrel.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P5_S0	over the market price through the use of purchased calls.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P5_S1	For further discussion of our derivative instruments and activities, see Note 4 , Derivative Financial Instruments to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 of this report.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P6_S0	At December 31, 2015 , our debt was comprised of:
912750_16_ITEM7A_P7_S0	We consider our interest rate exposure to be minimal because 98% of our obligations were at fixed rates as of December 31, 2015 , and our variable rate debt was at a weighted-average interest rate of approximately 2%.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P7_S1	A 10% increase in LIBOR would not materially impact our interest costs on debt outstanding at December 31, 2015 , but would decrease the fair value of our outstanding debt, as well as increase interest costs associated with future debt issuances or borrowings under our revolving credit facility and money market lines of credit.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The functional currency for our China operations is the U.S. dollar.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P8_S1	To the extent that business transactions in a foreign country are not denominated in the U.S. dollar, we are exposed to foreign currency exchange risk.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P8_S2	We consider our current risk exposure to exchange rate movements, based on net cash flows, to be immaterial.
912750_16_ITEM7A_P8_S3	We did not have any open derivative contracts related to foreign currencies at December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	Our Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(f).
912750_16_ITEM8_P0_S1	Internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of our financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
912750_16_ITEM8_P0_S2	Under the supervision and with the participation of our Company s management, including the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer, we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
912750_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	Our internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that: (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of our assets; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of our financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that our receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of our management and directors; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of our assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
912750_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	Based on our evaluation under the framework in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013), the management of our Company concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	The effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015 has been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in their report that follows.
912750_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of Newfield Exploration Company:
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated balance sheet and the related consolidated statements of operations, of comprehensive income, of stockholders equity and of cash flows present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Newfield Exploration Company and its subsidiaries at December 31, 2015 and 2014 , and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2015 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S1	Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015 , based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework 2013 issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S2	The Company's management is responsible for these financial statements, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management's Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S3	Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements and on the Company's internal control over financial reporting based on our integrated audits.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S4	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S6	Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S7	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S8	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
912750_16_ITEM8_P6_S9	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
912750_16_ITEM8_P7_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P8_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
912750_16_ITEM8_P9_S0	The accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements are an integral part of this statement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P10_S0	The accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements are an integral part of this statement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P11_S0	The accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements are an integral part of this statement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P12_S0	The accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements are an integral part of this statement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	The accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements are an integral part of this statement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P14_S0	We are an independent energy company engaged in the exploration, development and production of crude oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids (NGLs).
912750_16_ITEM8_P14_S1	Our operations are focused primarily on large scale, onshore liquids-rich resource plays in the United States.
912750_16_ITEM8_P14_S2	Our principal areas of operation are the Anadarko and Arkoma basins of Oklahoma, the Williston Basin of North Dakota, the Uinta Basin of Utah and the Maverick and Gulf Coast basins of Texas.
912750_16_ITEM8_P14_S3	In addition, we have oil developments offshore China.
912750_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	Our consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Newfield Exploration Company, a Delaware corporation, and its subsidiaries.
912750_16_ITEM8_P15_S1	We proportionately consolidate our interests in oil and natural gas exploration and production ventures and partnerships in accordance with industry practice.
912750_16_ITEM8_P15_S2	All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
912750_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	Unless otherwise specified or the context otherwise requires, all references in these notes to Newfield, we, us, our or the Company are to Newfield Exploration Company and its subsidiaries.
912750_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	As an independent oil and natural gas producer, our revenue, profitability and future rate of growth are substantially dependent on prevailing prices for oil, natural gas and NGLs.
912750_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Historically, the energy markets have been very volatile, and there can be no assurance that commodity prices will not be subject to wide fluctuations in the future.
912750_16_ITEM8_P18_S1	A substantial or extended decline in commodity prices could have a material adverse effect on our financial position, results of operations, cash flows, access to capital and on the quantities of oil, natural gas and NGL reserves that we can economically produce.
912750_16_ITEM8_P18_S2	Other risks and uncertainties that could affect us in the current price environment include, but are not limited to, counterparty credit risk for our receivables, responsibility for decommissioning liabilities for offshore interests we no longer own, access to credit markets and ability to meet financial ratios and covenants in our financing agreements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires our management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities; disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements; the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period; and the quantities and values of proved oil, natural gas and NGL reserves used in calculating depletion and assessing impairment of our oil and gas properties.
912750_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	Actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
912750_16_ITEM8_P19_S2	Our most significant estimates are associated with the quantities of proved oil, natural gas and NGL reserves, the timing and amount of transfers of our unevaluated properties into our amortizable full cost pool, the recoverability of our deferred tax assets and the fair value of both our derivative contracts and our stock-based compensation liability awards.
912750_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	Restructuring costs include severance and related benefit costs, costs associated with abandoned office space, employee relocation costs and other associated costs.
912750_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	Employee severance and related benefit costs are recognized on a straight-line basis over the required service period, if any.
912750_16_ITEM8_P20_S2	Employee relocation costs are expensed as incurred.
912750_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	On the date a leased property ceases to be used, a liability for non-cancellable office-lease costs associated with restructuring is recognized and measured at fair value on our consolidated balance sheet.
912750_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	Fair value estimates include assumptions regarding estimated future sublease payments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P22_S1	These estimates could materially differ from actual results and may require revision to initial estimates of the liability.
912750_16_ITEM8_P22_S2	See Note 16 , "Restructuring Costs," for additional disclosures.
912750_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	Certain reclassifications were made to prior years reported amounts in order to conform to the current year presentation.
912750_16_ITEM8_P23_S1	These reclassifications did not impact our net income (loss), stockholders equity or cash flows.
912750_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	The Company's production and other taxes for continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 were reduced by approximately $ 7 million in the fourth quarter due to an adjustment related to our 2013 and 2014 severance tax returns.
912750_16_ITEM8_P24_S1	The Company does not believe the correcting adjustments are material to these consolidated financial statements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	See Note 19 , "Discontinued Operations," for additional disclosures, as well as information regarding the sale of our Malaysia business, which closed in February 2014.
912750_16_ITEM8_P25_S1	These financial statements and notes are inclusive of our Malaysia operations unless otherwise noted.
912750_16_ITEM8_P26_S0	Substantially all of our oil, natural gas and NGLs are sold at market-based prices to a variety of purchasers under short-term contracts (less than 12 months).
912750_16_ITEM8_P26_S1	We also have long-term contracts in the Uinta Basin at market-based prices, less a variable differential that becomes fixed below certain market price thresholds.
912750_16_ITEM8_P26_S2	We record revenue when we deliver our production to the customer and collectability is reasonably assured.
912750_16_ITEM8_P26_S3	Revenues from the production of oil, natural gas and NGLs on properties in which we have joint ownership are recorded under the sales method.
912750_16_ITEM8_P27_S0	Under the sales method, the Company and other joint owners may sell more or less than their entitled share of production.
912750_16_ITEM8_P27_S1	Should the Company s excess sales exceed our share of estimated remaining recoverable reserves, a liability is recorded.
912750_16_ITEM8_P28_S0	Differences between sales and our entitled share of production are not material.
912750_16_ITEM8_P29_S0	The functional currency for our China operations is the U.S. dollar.
912750_16_ITEM8_P29_S1	Gains and losses incurred on transactions in a currency other than the U.S. dollar are recorded under the caption Other income (expense) Other, net on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P30_S0	Cash and cash equivalents include highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when acquired and are stated at cost, which approximates fair value.
912750_16_ITEM8_P30_S1	We invest cash in excess of near-term capital and operating requirements in U.S. Treasury Notes, Eurodollar time deposits and money market funds, which are classified as cash and cash equivalents on our consolidated balance sheet.
912750_16_ITEM8_P31_S0	We have restricted cash of $13 million included in "Other assets" on our consolidated balance sheet at December 31, 2015 that represents amounts held in escrow accounts to satisfy future plug and abandonment obligations for our China operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P31_S1	These amounts are restricted as to their current use and will be released as we plug and abandon wells and facilities in our China field.
912750_16_ITEM8_P31_S2	Consistent with our other plug and abandonment activities, changes in restricted cash are included in cash flows from operating activities in our consolidated statement of cash flows.
912750_16_ITEM8_P32_S0	Investments consist of debt and equity securities, a majority of which are classified as available-for-sale and stated at fair value.
912750_16_ITEM8_P32_S1	Accordingly, unrealized gains and losses and the related deferred income tax effects are excluded from earnings and reported in other comprehensive income within our consolidated statement of stockholders' equity.
912750_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	Realized gains or losses are computed based on specific identification of the securities sold.
912750_16_ITEM8_P33_S1	We regularly assess our investments for impairment and consider any impairment to be other than temporary if we intend to sell the security, it is more likely than not that we will be required to sell the security, or we do not expect to recover our cost of the security.
912750_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	We routinely assess material trade and other receivables to determine their collectability.
912750_16_ITEM8_P34_S1	Many of our receivables are from joint interest owners of properties we operate.
912750_16_ITEM8_P34_S2	Thus, we may have the ability to withhold future revenue disbursements to recover any non-payment of joint interest billings.
912750_16_ITEM8_P35_S0	We accrue a reserve on a receivable when, based on the judgment of management, it is probable that a receivable will not be collected.
912750_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	Inventories primarily consist of tubular goods and well equipment held for use in our oil and natural gas operations and oil produced but not sold in our China operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P36_S1	Inventories are carried at the lower of cost or market.
912750_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	Substantially all of the crude oil from our offshore operations in China is produced into floating storage facilities and sold periodically as barge quantities are accumulated.
912750_16_ITEM8_P37_S1	The carrying value of oil inventory is the sum of related production costs and depletion expense.
912750_16_ITEM8_P37_S2	See Note 3 , "Inventories," for further discussion.
912750_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	We use the full cost method of accounting for our oil and gas activities.
912750_16_ITEM8_P38_S1	Under this method, all costs incurred in the acquisition, exploration and development of oil and gas properties, including salaries, benefits, interest and other internal costs directly attributable to these activities, are capitalized into country-based cost centers.
912750_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	Proceeds from the sale of oil and gas properties are applied to reduce the costs in the applicable cost center unless the reduction would significantly alter the relationship between capitalized costs and proved reserves, in which case a gain or loss is recognized.
912750_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	During the first quarter of 2014, we sold our Malaysia business, which constituted the entire full cost pool for Malaysia.
912750_16_ITEM8_P40_S1	See Note 19 , "Discontinued Operations," for further discussion.
912750_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	Capitalized costs and estimated future development costs are amortized using a unit-of-production method based on proved reserves associated with the applicable cost center.
912750_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	For each cost center, the net capitalized costs of oil and gas properties are limited to the lower of the unamortized cost or the cost center ceiling.
912750_16_ITEM8_P41_S2	A particular cost center ceiling is equal to the sum of:
912750_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	If net capitalized costs of oil and gas properties exceed the cost center ceiling, we are subject to a ceiling test writedown to the extent of such excess.
912750_16_ITEM8_P42_S1	If required, a ceiling test writedown reduces earnings and stockholders equity in the period of occurrence and, holding other factors constant, results in lower depreciation, depletion and amortization expense in future periods.
912750_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	The risk that we will be required to writedown the carrying value of our oil and gas properties increases when oil, natural gas and NGL prices decrease significantly for a prolonged period, or if we have substantial downward revisions in our estimated proved reserves.
912750_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	Costs associated with unevaluated properties are excluded from our amortization base until we have evaluated the properties or impairment is indicated.
912750_16_ITEM8_P44_S1	The costs associated with unevaluated leasehold acreage and related seismic data, wells currently drilling and capitalized interest are initially excluded from our amortization base.
912750_16_ITEM8_P44_S2	Leasehold costs are either transferred to our amortization base with the costs of drilling a well on the lease or are assessed at least annually for possible impairment or reduction in value.
912750_16_ITEM8_P44_S3	Leasehold costs are transferred to our amortization base to the extent a reduction in value has occurred, or a charge is made against earnings if the costs were incurred in a country for which a reserve base has not been established.
912750_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	See Note 6 , Oil and Gas Properties and Other Property and Equipment, for a detailed discussion regarding our oil and gas property and equipment, and our asset acquisitions and sales transactions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	Furniture, fixtures and equipment are recorded at cost and are depreciated using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives, which range from three to seven years.
912750_16_ITEM8_P46_S1	Gathering systems and equipment are recorded at cost and depreciated using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives of 25 years.
912750_16_ITEM8_P47_S0	If a reasonable estimate of the fair value of an obligation to perform site reclamation, dismantle facilities or plug and abandon wells can be made, we record a liability (an asset retirement obligation or ARO) on our consolidated balance sheet and capitalize the present value of the asset retirement cost in oil and gas properties in the period in which the ARO is incurred.
912750_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	Settlements include payments made to satisfy the AROs, as well as transfer of the AROs to purchasers of our divested properties.
912750_16_ITEM8_P48_S0	In general, the amount of the initial recorded ARO and the costs capitalized will equal the estimated future costs to satisfy the abandonment obligation assuming normal operation of the asset, using current prices that are escalated by an assumed inflation factor up to the estimated settlement date, which is then discounted back to the date that the abandonment obligation was incurred using the credit adjusted risk-free rate for our Company.
912750_16_ITEM8_P48_S1	After recording these amounts, the ARO is accreted to its future estimated value and the original capitalized costs are depreciated on a unit-of-production basis within the related full cost pool.
912750_16_ITEM8_P48_S2	Both the accretion and the depreciation are included in depreciation, depletion and amortization expense on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P48_S3	See Note 9 , "Asset Retirement Obligations," for further discussion.
912750_16_ITEM8_P49_S0	We are subject to legal proceedings, claims, liabilities and environmental matters that arise in the ordinary course of business.
912750_16_ITEM8_P49_S1	We accrue for losses when such losses are considered probable and the amounts can be reasonably estimated.
912750_16_ITEM8_P49_S2	See Note 11 , Commitments and Contingencies, for a more detailed discussion regarding our contingencies.
912750_16_ITEM8_P50_S0	Environmental costs that relate to current operations are expensed as incurred.
912750_16_ITEM8_P50_S1	Remediation costs that relate to an existing condition caused by past operations are accrued when it is probable that those costs will be incurred and can be reasonably estimated based upon evaluations of currently available facts related to each site.
912750_16_ITEM8_P51_S0	We use the liability method of accounting for income taxes.
912750_16_ITEM8_P51_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined by applying tax regulations existing at the end of a reporting period to the cumulative temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their reported amounts in our financial statements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P52_S0	We assess the available positive and negative evidence to estimate if sufficient taxable income will be generated to utilize deferred tax assets.
912750_16_ITEM8_P52_S1	A valuation allowance is established to reduce deferred tax assets if it is more likely than not that the related tax benefits will not be realized.
912750_16_ITEM8_P52_S2	We also evaluate potential uncertain tax positions, and if necessary, establish accruals for such items.
912750_16_ITEM8_P52_S3	See Note 7 , "Income Taxes," for further discussion.
912750_16_ITEM8_P53_S0	We apply a fair value-based method of accounting for stock-based compensation, which requires recognition in the financial statements of the cost of services received in exchange for awards of equity instruments based on the grant date fair value of those awards.
912750_16_ITEM8_P53_S1	For equity awards, compensation expense is based on the fair value on the grant or modification date and is recognized in our financial statements over the vesting period.
912750_16_ITEM8_P53_S2	We utilize the Black-Scholes option-pricing model to measure the fair value of stock options and a Monte Carlo lattice-based model for our performance and market-based restricted stock and restricted stock units.
912750_16_ITEM8_P53_S3	We also have cash-settled restricted stock units that are accounted for under the liability method, which requires us to recognize the fair value of each award based on the underlying share price at the end of each period.
912750_16_ITEM8_P53_S4	See Note 14 , Stock-Based Compensation, for a full discussion of our stock-based compensation.
912750_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	We operate a substantial portion of our oil and gas properties.
912750_16_ITEM8_P54_S1	As the operator of a property, we make full payment for costs associated with the property and seek reimbursement from the other working interest owners in the property for their share of those costs.
912750_16_ITEM8_P54_S2	Our joint interest owners consist primarily of independent oil and gas producers whose ability to reimburse us could be negatively impacted by adverse market conditions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	The purchasers of our oil, gas and NGL production consist primarily of independent marketers, major oil and gas companies, refiners and gas pipeline companies.
912750_16_ITEM8_P55_S1	We perform credit evaluations of the purchasers of our production and monitor their financial condition on an ongoing basis.
912750_16_ITEM8_P55_S2	Based on our evaluations and monitoring, we obtain cash escrows, letters of credit or parental guarantees from some purchasers.
912750_16_ITEM8_P56_S0	All of our derivative transactions were carried out in the over-the-counter market and are not typically subject to margin-deposit requirements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S0	The use of derivative transactions involves the risk that the counterparties will be unable to meet the financial terms of such transactions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S1	The counterparties for all of our derivative transactions have an investment grade credit rating.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S2	We monitor the credit ratings of our hedging counterparties on an ongoing basis.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S3	Although we have entered into derivative contracts with multiple counterparties to mitigate our exposure to any individual counterparty, if any of our counterparties were to default on its obligations to us under the derivative contracts or seek bankruptcy protection, it could have a material adverse effect on our ability to fund our planned activities and could result in a larger percentage of our future production being subject to commodity price volatility.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S4	In addition, in poor economic environments and tight financial markets, the risk of a counterparty default is heightened and fewer counterparties may participate in derivative transactions, which could result in greater concentration of our exposure to any one counterparty or a larger percentage of our future production being subject to commodity price changes.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S5	At December 31, 2015 , 10 of our 15 counterparties accounted for approximately 85% of our contracted volumes, with the largest counterparty accounting for approximately 15% .
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S6	Approximately 70% of our volumes subject to derivative instruments are with lenders under our credit facility.
912750_16_ITEM8_P57_S7	Our credit facility, senior notes and substantially all of our derivative instruments contain provisions that provide for cross defaults and acceleration of those debt and derivative instruments in certain situations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P58_S0	China National Offshore Oil Corporation Ltd., MidCon Gathering LLC and Sunoco Logistics Partners Operations GP LLC accounted for 13% , 11% and 10% , respectively, of our total revenues in 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P58_S1	During 2014 , Tesoro Corporation and Sunoco Logistics Partners Operations GP LLC accounted for 12% and 10% , respectively, of our total revenues.
912750_16_ITEM8_P58_S2	During 2013 , sales of our oil and gas production to Sunoco Logistics Partners Operations GP LLC, Royal Dutch Shell plc and Tesoro Corporation accounted for 13% , 12% and 11% , respectively, of our total revenues.
912750_16_ITEM8_P58_S3	We believe that the loss of any of our major customers would not have a material adverse effect on us because alternative purchasers are available.
912750_16_ITEM8_P59_S0	Our derivative instruments are recorded on the consolidated balance sheet at fair value as either an asset or a liability with changes in fair value recognized currently in earnings.
912750_16_ITEM8_P59_S1	While we utilize our derivative instruments to manage the price risk attributable to our expected oil and gas production, we have elected not to designate our derivative instruments as accounting hedges under the accounting guidance.
912750_16_ITEM8_P60_S0	The related cash flow impact of our derivative activities are reflected as cash flows from operating activities unless they are determined to have a significant financing element at inception, in which case they are classified within financing activities.
912750_16_ITEM8_P60_S1	See Note 4 , Derivative Financial Instruments, for a more detailed discussion of our derivative activities.
912750_16_ITEM8_P61_S0	Our derivative financial instruments are subject to master netting arrangements and are reflected on our consolidated balance sheet accordingly.
912750_16_ITEM8_P61_S1	See Note 4 , "Derivative Financial Instruments," for details regarding the gross amounts, as well as the impact of our netting arrangements on our net derivative position.
912750_16_ITEM8_P62_S0	We only offset assets and liabilities in relation to our derivative financial instruments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	In November 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued guidance regarding the presentation of deferred income taxes in the balance sheet and requires that within a particular jurisdiction, deferred tax liabilities and assets, as well as any related valuation allowance, be offset and classified as a single noncurrent amount.
912750_16_ITEM8_P63_S1	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
912750_16_ITEM8_P63_S2	We early adopted this guidance in 2015 on a prospective basis as permitted by the guidance.
912750_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued guidance regarding the presentation of debt issuance costs in the financial statements and requires that debt issuance costs be presented as a reduction of the carrying value of the financial liability and not as a separate asset.
912750_16_ITEM8_P64_S1	The guidance requires retrospective adjustment to the balance sheet presentation and disclosures applicable for a change in an accounting principle.
912750_16_ITEM8_P64_S2	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015.
912750_16_ITEM8_P64_S3	We early adopted this guidance in 2015 as permitted by the guidance.

912750_16_ITEM8_P65_S1	The guidance applies prospectively to all entities, requiring management to evaluate whether there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern and disclose certain information when substantial doubt is raised.
912750_16_ITEM8_P65_S2	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2016.
912750_16_ITEM8_P65_S3	We will adopt this guidance in the first quarter of 2017.

912750_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	We utilize the following derivative strategies, which consist of either a single derivative instrument or a combination of instruments, to manage the variability in cash flows associated with the forecasted sale of our domestic oil and natural gas production.
912750_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	With respect to a swap position, the counterparty is required to make a payment to us if the settlement price for any settlement period is less than the swap strike price, and we are required to make a payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any settlement period is greater than the swap strike price.
912750_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	Collars (combination of purchased put options (floor) and sold call options (ceiling)) .
912750_16_ITEM8_P72_S1	For a collar position, the counterparty is required to make a payment to us if the settlement price for any settlement period is below the floor strike price while we are required to make payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any settlement period is above the ceiling strike price.
912750_16_ITEM8_P72_S2	Neither party is required to make a payment to the other party if the settlement price for any settlement period is equal to or greater than the floor strike price and equal to or less than the ceiling strike price.
912750_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	A swap with a sold put position consists of a standard swap position plus a put sold by us with a strike price below the associated fixed-price swap.
912750_16_ITEM8_P73_S1	This structure enables us to increase the fixed-price swap with the value received through the sale of the put.
912750_16_ITEM8_P73_S2	If the settlement price for any settlement period falls equal to or below the put strike price, then we will only receive the difference between the swap price and the put strike price.
912750_16_ITEM8_P73_S3	If the settlement price is greater than the put strike price, the result is the same as it would have been with a standard swap only.
912750_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	A collar with a sold put position consists of a standard collar position plus a put sold by us with a strike price below the floor strike price of the collar.
912750_16_ITEM8_P74_S1	This structure enables us to improve the collar strike prices with the value received through the sale of the additional put.
912750_16_ITEM8_P74_S2	If the settlement price for any settlement period falls equal to or below the additional put strike price, then we will receive the difference between the floor strike price and the additional put strike price.
912750_16_ITEM8_P74_S3	If the settlement price is greater than the additional put strike price, the result is the same as it would have been with a standard collar only.
912750_16_ITEM8_P75_S0	These purchased calls are options that require a counterparty to make a payment to us if the settlement price is above the call strike price (excluding the effects of deferred premium owed by us to the counterparty).
912750_16_ITEM8_P75_S1	As a result, these positions lock in the value of a portion of our corresponding oil swaps with sold puts as well as collars with sold puts.
912750_16_ITEM8_P75_S2	Our total deferred premium associated with these purchased calls was $22 million at December 31, 2015.
912750_16_ITEM8_P76_S0	While the use of these derivative instruments may limit or partially reduce the downside risk of adverse commodity price movements, their use also may limit future income from favorable commodity price movements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	Our oil and gas derivative contracts are settled based upon reported prices on the NYMEX.
912750_16_ITEM8_P77_S1	The estimated fair value of these contracts is based upon various factors, including closing exchange prices on the NYMEX, over-the-counter quotations, estimated volatility, non-performance risk adjustments using credit default swaps, interest rates and time to maturity.
912750_16_ITEM8_P78_S0	The calculation of the fair value of options requires the use of an option-pricing model.
912750_16_ITEM8_P78_S1	See Note 5 , Fair Value Measurements.
912750_16_ITEM8_P79_S0	At December 31, 2015 , we had outstanding derivative positions as set forth in the tables below.
912750_16_ITEM8_P80_S0	_________________ (1) If the market prices remain below our sold puts at contract settlement, we will receive the market price plus the following associated with our production:
912750_16_ITEM8_P81_S0	the difference between our swap price and our sold put price for fixed-price swaps with sold puts.
912750_16_ITEM8_P81_S1	For the volumes with purchased calls, we have effectively locked in a portion of the difference between the purchased call price and the sold put price noted above (less the deferred call premium).
912750_16_ITEM8_P82_S0	We had derivative financial instruments recorded in our consolidated balance sheet as assets (liabilities) at their respective estimated fair value, as set forth below.
912750_16_ITEM8_P83_S0	The amount of gain (loss) recognized in Commodity derivative income (expense) in our consolidated statement of operations related to our derivative financial instruments follows:
912750_16_ITEM8_P84_S0	Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
912750_16_ITEM8_P84_S1	The authoritative guidance requires disclosure of the framework for measuring fair value and requires that fair value measurements be classified and disclosed in one of the following categories:
912750_16_ITEM8_P85_S0	Level 1: Unadjusted quoted prices in active markets that are accessible at the measurement date for identical, unrestricted assets or liabilities.
912750_16_ITEM8_P85_S1	We consider active markets as those in which transactions for the assets or liabilities occur with sufficient frequency and volume to provide pricing information on an ongoing basis.
912750_16_ITEM8_P86_S0	Level 2: Quoted prices in markets that are not active, or inputs that are observable, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
912750_16_ITEM8_P86_S1	This category includes those derivative instruments that we value using observable market data.
912750_16_ITEM8_P86_S2	Substantially all of these inputs are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the derivative instrument, can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable levels at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
912750_16_ITEM8_P87_S0	Instruments in this category include non-exchange traded derivatives such as over-the-counter commodity fixed-price swaps and certain investments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P88_S0	Level 3: Measured based on prices or valuation models that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and less observable from objective sources (i.e., supported by little or no market activity).
912750_16_ITEM8_P88_S1	Level 3 instruments primarily include derivative instruments, such as commodity options (i.e., price collars, sold puts, purchased calls or swaptions) and other financial investments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P89_S0	Our valuation models for derivative contracts are primarily industry-standard models (i.e., Black-Scholes) that consider various inputs including: (a) forward prices for commodities, (b) time value, (c) volatility factors, (d) counterparty credit risk and (e) current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P90_S0	Our valuation model for the Stockholder Value Appreciation Program (SVAP) is a Monte Carlo simulation that is based on a probability model and considers various inputs including: (a) the measurement date stock price, (b) time value and (c) historical and implied volatility.
912750_16_ITEM8_P90_S1	See Note 14 , Stock-Based Compensation, for a description of the SVAP.
912750_16_ITEM8_P91_S0	Financial assets and liabilities are classified based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P91_S1	Our assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement requires judgment and may affect the valuation of the fair value of assets and liabilities and their placement within the fair value hierarchy.
912750_16_ITEM8_P92_S0	The determination of the fair values of our derivative contracts incorporates various factors, which include not only the impact of our non-performance risk on our liabilities but also the credit standing of the counterparties involved and the impact of credit enhancements (such as cash deposits, letters of credit and priority interests), if any.
912750_16_ITEM8_P92_S1	We utilize credit default swap values to assess the impact of non-performance risk when evaluating both our liabilities to, and receivables from, counterparties.
912750_16_ITEM8_P93_S0	The following table summarizes the valuation of our assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis.
912750_16_ITEM8_P94_S0	The following table sets forth a reconciliation of changes in the fair value of financial assets and liabilities classified as Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy for the indicated periods.
912750_16_ITEM8_P95_S0	________ (1) During the second quarter of 2014, we transferred $3 million of derivative option contracts out of the Level 3 hierarchy.
912750_16_ITEM8_P95_S1	The transfer was a result of our Level 3 swaptions being exercised by the counterparties as swaps on May 30, 2014.
912750_16_ITEM8_P96_S0	During the first quarter of 2014, all auction rate securities that we held as of January 1, 2014, were sold for $39 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P97_S0	Our valuation models for Level 3 derivative contracts are primarily industry-standard models that consider various factors, including certain significant unobservable inputs such as volatility factors and counterparty credit risk.
912750_16_ITEM8_P98_S0	The calculation of the fair value of our option contracts requires the use of an option-pricing model.
912750_16_ITEM8_P99_S0	compared to the strike prices fixed by our derivative contracts, and the resulting estimated future cash inflows or outflows over the contractual life are discounted to calculate the fair value.
912750_16_ITEM8_P99_S1	These pricing and discounting variables are sensitive to market volatility as well as changes in future price forecasts, regional price differences and interest rates.
912750_16_ITEM8_P100_S0	Significant increases (decreases) in the quoted forward prices for commodities generally lead to corresponding decreases (increases) in the fair value measurement of our oil and gas derivative contracts.
912750_16_ITEM8_P101_S0	Significant changes in the volatility factors utilized in our option-pricing model can cause significant changes in the fair value measurement of our oil and gas derivative contracts.
912750_16_ITEM8_P101_S1	Historically, we have not experienced significant changes in the fair value of our derivative contracts resulting from changes in counterparty credit risk as the counterparties for all of our derivative transactions have an investment grade credit rating.
912750_16_ITEM8_P101_S2	See Note 4 , "Derivative Financial Instruments," for additional discussion of our derivative instruments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P102_S0	The calculation of the fair value of the SVAP liability required the use of a probability-based Monte Carlo simulation, which included unobservable inputs.
912750_16_ITEM8_P102_S1	The simulation predicted multiple scenarios of future stock returns over the performance period, which were discounted to calculate the fair value.
912750_16_ITEM8_P102_S2	The fair value was recognized over a service period derived from the simulation.
912750_16_ITEM8_P102_S3	The SVAP performance period ended December 31, 2015.

912750_16_ITEM8_P118_S0	The following table presents a reconciliation of the United States statutory income tax rate to our effective income tax rate.
912750_16_ITEM8_P119_S0	Our effective tax rate for 2015 differs from the U.S. statutory rate primarily due to domestic and international deferred tax asset valuation allowances recorded in 2015 and discussed below.
912750_16_ITEM8_P120_S0	In the fourth quarter of 2012, we elected to have our China business treated as a disregarded entity for U.S. federal income tax purposes, which resulted in earnings and profits of our international business in China being taxed in both the United States and China.
912750_16_ITEM8_P120_S1	Due to our net operating loss (NOL) carryforward position, we do not expect to be able to utilize related foreign tax credits (FTC) before they expire and accordingly we recorded a full valuation allowance against these credits.
912750_16_ITEM8_P120_S2	These FTCs are utilized in the alternative minimum tax system to reduce current cash taxes.
912750_16_ITEM8_P120_S3	The result is a high effective tax rate in periods, such as 2013, when our book income in China is high relative to our domestic book income.
912750_16_ITEM8_P120_S4	These effective tax rate fluctuations are magnified when income before taxes approaches zero.
912750_16_ITEM8_P121_S0	At December 31, the components of our deferred tax asset (liability) were as follows:
912750_16_ITEM8_P122_S0	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014 , we had gross NOL carryforwards of approximately $852 million and $573 million for federal income tax and $1.8 billion and $1.6 billion for state income tax purposes, respectively, which may be used in future years to offset taxable income.
912750_16_ITEM8_P122_S1	At December 31, 2015 , our gross NOL included unrecognized net operating losses of $108 million related to stock-based compensation.
912750_16_ITEM8_P122_S2	NOL carryforwards of $155 million are subject to annual limitations due to stock ownership changes.
912750_16_ITEM8_P122_S3	We currently estimate that we will not be able to utilize $61 million of our various gross state NOLs because we do not have sufficient estimated future taxable income in the appropriate jurisdictions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P122_S4	To the extent not utilized, the federal NOL carryforwards will begin to expire during the years 2019 through 2035.
912750_16_ITEM8_P123_S0	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014, we had foreign tax credits of approximately $ 572 million and $ 547 million, respectively, which will expire during the years 2022 through 2025.
912750_16_ITEM8_P124_S0	Utilization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon generating sufficient future taxable income in the appropriate jurisdictions within the carryforward period.
912750_16_ITEM8_P125_S0	Estimates of future taxable income can be significantly affected by changes in oil, gas and NGL prices; estimates of the timing and amount of future production; and estimates of future operating and capital costs.
912750_16_ITEM8_P125_S1	Therefore, no certainty exists that we will be able to fully utilize our existing deferred tax assets.
912750_16_ITEM8_P126_S0	The change in our deferred tax asset valuation allowance is as follows at December 31:
912750_16_ITEM8_P127_S0	Due to the ceiling test writedowns of our oil and gas properties in 2015, we moved from a deferred tax liability position to a deferred tax asset position in various taxing jurisdictions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P127_S1	With the current commodity price levels, we consider it more likely than not that the related tax benefits will not be realized and therefore, we recorded a full valuation allowance on our domestic and China deferred tax assets of $202 million and $13 million, respectively.
912750_16_ITEM8_P128_S0	As the result of the divestiture of the Malaysia operations in 2014, all of the deferred tax asset and related valuation allowance were transferred to the buyer.
912750_16_ITEM8_P128_S1	In the fourth quarter of 2014, we wrote off the other international deferred tax assets and related valuation allowances since we have ceased operating in these jurisdictions and it is remote that the NOL carryforwards will be realized in the future.
912750_16_ITEM8_P128_S2	In fourth quarter of 2015, 2014 and 2013, we recorded valuation allowances related to insufficient estimated future domestic taxable income to fully utilize foreign tax credits before they expire of $ 25 million , $12 million , and $ 114 million , respectively.
912750_16_ITEM8_P129_S0	The foreign tax credit deferred tax asset is fully offset by a valuation allowance.
912750_16_ITEM8_P130_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we did not have a liability for uncertain tax positions, and as such, we did not accrue related interest or penalties.
912750_16_ITEM8_P130_S1	The tax years 2011 through 2015 remain open to examination for federal income tax purposes and by the other major taxing jurisdictions to which we are subject.
912750_16_ITEM8_P131_S0	Unrealized derivative gains and losses are treated differently for income tax purposes in the various state taxing jurisdictions to which we are subject.
912750_16_ITEM8_P131_S1	As a result, our effective tax rate fluctuates in periods with significant commodity price volatility.
912750_16_ITEM8_P131_S2	These effective tax rate fluctuations are magnified when income before taxes approaches zero.
