912750_16_ITEM8_P137_S0	In March 2015, we entered into the fourth amendment to our Credit Agreement.
912750_16_ITEM8_P137_S1	This amendment extended the maturity date of the revolving credit facility from June 2018 to June 2020 and increased the borrowing capacity from $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion .
912750_16_ITEM8_P137_S2	We incurred $7 million of financing costs related to this amendment, which were deferred and will be amortized through June 2020.
912750_16_ITEM8_P138_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , the largest individual loan commitment by any lender was 12% of total commitments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P139_S0	Loans under the credit facility bear interest, at our option, equal to (a) a rate per annum equal to the higher of the prime rate announced from time to time by JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. or the weighted average of the rates on overnight federal funds transactions with members of the Federal Reserve System during the last preceding business day plus 50 basis points, plus a margin that is based on a grid of our debt rating ( 75 basis points per annum at December 31, 2015 ) or (b) the London Interbank Offered Rate, plus a margin that is based on a grid of our debt rating ( 175 basis points per annum at December 31, 2015 ).
912750_16_ITEM8_P140_S0	Under our credit facility, we pay commitment fees on available but undrawn amounts based on a grid of our debt rating ( 30 basis points per annum at December 31, 2015 ).
912750_16_ITEM8_P140_S1	We incurred aggregate commitment fees under our credit facility of approximately $5 million , $4 million and $3 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively, which are recorded in Interest expense on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P141_S0	Our credit facility has restrictive financial covenants that include the maintenance of a ratio of total debt to book capitalization not to exceed 0.6 to 1.0 and maintenance of a ratio of earnings before gain or loss on the disposition of assets, interest expense, income taxes and noncash items (such as depreciation, depletion and amortization expense, unrealized gains and losses on commodity derivatives and ceiling test writedowns) to interest expense of at least 3.0 to 1.0.
912750_16_ITEM8_P141_S1	At December 31, 2015 , we were in compliance with all of our debt covenants.
912750_16_ITEM8_P142_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we had no letters of credit outstanding under our credit facility.
912750_16_ITEM8_P142_S1	Letters of credit are subject to a fronting fee of 20 basis points and annual fees based on a grid of our debt rating ( 175 basis points at December 31, 2015 ).
912750_16_ITEM8_P143_S0	Subject to compliance with the restrictive covenants in our credit facility, at December 31, 2015 , we also had a total of $156 million of available borrowing capacity under money market lines of credit with various financial institutions, the availability of which is at the discretion of the financial institutions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P144_S0	The credit facility includes events of default relating to customary matters, including, among other things, nonpayment of principal, interest or other amounts; violation of covenants; inaccuracy of representations and warranties in any material respect; a change of control; or certain other material adverse changes in our business.
912750_16_ITEM8_P144_S1	Our senior notes also contain standard events of default.
912750_16_ITEM8_P144_S2	If any of the foregoing defaults were to occur, our lenders under the credit facility could terminate future lending commitments, and our lenders under both the credit facility and our notes could declare the outstanding borrowings due and payable.
912750_16_ITEM8_P144_S3	In addition, our credit facility, senior notes and substantially all of our derivative arrangements contain provisions that provide for cross defaults and acceleration of those debt and derivative instruments in certain situations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P144_S4	See Note 1 , "Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies Concentration of Credit Risk ," for additional details.
912750_16_ITEM8_P145_S0	In March 2015, we issued $700 million of 5 % Senior Notes due 2026 and received net proceeds of $691 million (net of offering costs of approximately $9 million ).
912750_16_ITEM8_P145_S1	These notes were issued at par to yield 5 %.
912750_16_ITEM8_P145_S2	In April 2015, we used the net proceeds and cash on hand to redeem our $700 million aggregate principal amount of 6 % Senior Subordinated Notes due 2020.
912750_16_ITEM8_P145_S3	In connection with the redemption, we paid a premium of $24 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P145_S4	Other, net" on our consolidated statement of income.
912750_16_ITEM8_P145_S5	In addition, associated unamortized offering costs and discounts of approximately $8 million were charged to interest expense during the second quarter of 2015 as a result of the redemption.
912750_16_ITEM8_P146_S0	Interest on our senior notes is payable semi-annually.
912750_16_ITEM8_P146_S1	The notes are unsecured and unsubordinated obligations and rank equally with all of our other existing and future unsecured and unsubordinated obligations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P146_S2	We may redeem some or all of our senior notes at any time before their maturity at a redemption price based on a make-whole amount plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of redemption.
912750_16_ITEM8_P146_S3	The indentures governing our senior notes contain covenants that may limit our ability to, among other things, incur debt secured by liens; enter into sale/leaseback transactions; and enter into merger or consolidation transactions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P146_S4	The indentures also provide that if any of our subsidiaries guarantee any of our indebtedness at any time in the future, then we will cause our senior notes to be equally and ratably guaranteed by that subsidiary.
912750_16_ITEM8_P147_S0	In October 2014, we redeemed our $600 million aggregate principal amount of 7 % Senior Subordinated Notes due 2018.
912750_16_ITEM8_P147_S1	In connection with the redemption, we paid a premium of $14 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P147_S2	Other, net" on our consolidated statement of operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P147_S3	In addition, unamortized offering costs of approximately $3 million were charged to interest expense as a result of the repayment.

912750_16_ITEM8_P151_S0	We have various oil and gas production volume delivery commitments that are related to our domestic operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P151_S1	As of December 31, 2015 , our delivery commitments through 2025 were as follows:
912750_16_ITEM8_P152_S0	_________________ (1) Our oil delivery commitments are with two Salt Lake City, Utah refiners and relate to our Uinta Basin production.
912750_16_ITEM8_P152_S1	One delivery commitment is for approximately 18,000 barrels of oil per day through 2020.
912750_16_ITEM8_P152_S2	The second commitment is for 15,000 barrels of oil per day in January 2016, increasing to 20,000 barrels of oil per day by the end of the third quarter 2016, and continues at that level through August 2025.
912750_16_ITEM8_P153_S0	Given the decline in oil and natural gas prices and the related impact on our 2016 planned capital investments, as well as the potential impact on development plans in future years, we could fail to deliver the minimum production required under these commitments.
912750_16_ITEM8_P153_S1	In the event that we are unable to meet our crude oil volume delivery commitments, we would incur deficiency fees ranging from $3.50 to $6.50 per barrel.
912750_16_ITEM8_P154_S0	In May 2015, a lawsuit was filed against the Company alleging certain plugging and abandonment predecessor-in-interest liabilities related to offshore assets sold by the Company in 2010.
912750_16_ITEM8_P154_S1	The lawsuit alleges damages of approximately $23 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P154_S2	The Company has responded to the petition, denied the allegations and is vigorously defending the case.
912750_16_ITEM8_P155_S0	The Court has held that the Company must bear a "portion" of the plugging and abandonment costs, but the "exact percentage" of such costs should be determined in arbitration.
912750_16_ITEM8_P155_S1	The court case is stayed pending arbitration.
912750_16_ITEM8_P156_S0	An estimate of reasonably possible losses, if any, cannot be made at this time.
912750_16_ITEM8_P157_S0	We have been named as a defendant in a number of lawsuits and are involved in various other disputes, all arising in the ordinary course of our business, such as (a) claims from royalty owners for disputed royalty payments, (b) commercial disputes, (c) personal injury claims and (d) property damage claims.
912750_16_ITEM8_P157_S1	Although the outcome of these lawsuits and disputes cannot be predicted with certainty, we do not expect these matters to have a material adverse effect on our financial position, cash flows or results of operations.

912750_16_ITEM8_P160_S0	During the first quarter of 2015, we issued 25.3 million additional shares of common stock through a public equity offering.
912750_16_ITEM8_P160_S1	We received net proceeds of approximately $815 million , which were used primarily to repay all borrowings under our credit facility and money market lines of credit that were outstanding at that time.
912750_16_ITEM8_P161_S0	In May 2015, our stockholders approved an amendment to the Company's Certificate of Incorporation that increased the total authorized shares of common stock from 200 million to 300 million shares.
912750_16_ITEM8_P162_S0	Upon vesting of employee restricted stock awards and restricted stock units, we typically repurchase a portion of the vested shares for payment of employee tax withholding.
912750_16_ITEM8_P162_S1	Such repurchases are not part of a publicly announced program to repurchase shares of our common stock.
912750_16_ITEM8_P163_S0	Basic earnings per share (EPS) is calculated by dividing net income, less any applicable adjustments, (the numerator) by the weighted-average number of shares of common stock (excluding unvested restricted stock and restricted stock units) outstanding during the period (the denominator).
912750_16_ITEM8_P163_S1	Diluted EPS incorporates the dilutive impact of outstanding stock options and unvested restricted stock and restricted stock units (using the treasury stock method).
912750_16_ITEM8_P164_S0	Under the treasury stock method, the amount the employee must pay for exercising stock options, the amount of unrecognized compensation expense related to unvested stock-based compensation grants and the amount of excess tax benefits that would be recorded when the award becomes deductible are assumed to be used to repurchase shares.
912750_16_ITEM8_P164_S1	See Note 14 , Stock-Based Compensation.
912750_16_ITEM8_P165_S0	The following is the calculation of basic and diluted weighted-average shares outstanding and EPS for the indicated years:
912750_16_ITEM8_P166_S0	_________________ (1) The effect of unvested restricted stock awards or restricted stock units and stock options has not been included in the calculation of shares outstanding for diluted EPS for the year ended December 31, 2015 , as their effect would have been anti-dilutive.
912750_16_ITEM8_P166_S1	Had we recognized income from continuing operations for the year, incremental shares attributable to the assumed vesting of unvested restricted stock awards and restricted stock units and the assumed exercise of outstanding stock options would have increased diluted weighted-averages shares outstanding by 2.8 million shares for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P166_S2	(2) The effect of 1.1 million and 4.0 million unvested restricted stock awards or restricted stock units and stock options for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively, have not been included in the calculation of shares outstanding for diluted EPS as their effect would have been anti-dilutive.
912750_16_ITEM8_P166_S3	(3) The numerator includes an adjustment of $20 million related to the repurchase of preferred shares of a now wholly-owned subsidiary, which reduces net income (loss) for purposes of earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2013.
912750_16_ITEM8_P166_S4	The subsidiary is part of our continuing operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P166_S5	See Note 20 , "Related Party Transaction," for additional information.
912750_16_ITEM8_P167_S0	For the years ended December 31, our stock-based compensation expense consisted of the following:
912750_16_ITEM8_P168_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we had approximately $50 million of total unrecognized stock-based compensation expense related to unvested stock-based compensation awards that vest within four years .
912750_16_ITEM8_P169_S0	Equity awards consist of service-based and performance- or market-based restricted stock awards and restricted stock units, stock options and stock purchase options under the Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP).
912750_16_ITEM8_P170_S0	Stock-based compensation classified as equity awards are currently granted under the 2011 Omnibus Stock Plan, as amended (2011 Plan), to employees and non-employee directors.
912750_16_ITEM8_P170_S1	The fair value of grants is determined utilizing the Black-Scholes option-pricing model for stock options and a Monte Carlo lattice-based model for our performance- and market-based restricted stock and restricted stock units.
912750_16_ITEM8_P171_S0	Compensation expense for equity awards is expected to be recognized on a straight-line basis over the applicable remaining vesting periods.
912750_16_ITEM8_P172_S0	Shares available for grant under our 2011 Plan are reduced by 1.87 times the number of shares of restricted stock or restricted stock units awarded under the plan and are reduced by 1 times the number of shares subject to stock options awarded under the plan.

912750_16_ITEM8_P172_S2	Thus far, all awards under our 2011 Plan have been granted as restricted stock or restricted stock unit awards.
912750_16_ITEM8_P172_S3	We utilize common shares when restricted stock awards are issued, options are exercised or restricted stock units vest.

912750_16_ITEM8_P181_S0	In May 2010, our stockholders approved the Newfield Exploration Company 2010 Employee Stock Purchase Plan with one million shares of our common stock available for issuance.
912750_16_ITEM8_P181_S1	Pursuant to our employee stock purchase plan, for each six-month period beginning on January 1 or July 1 during the term of the plan, each eligible employee has the opportunity to purchase our common stock for a purchase price equal to 85% of the lesser of the fair market value of our common stock on the first or last day of the period.
912750_16_ITEM8_P181_S2	Each employee may purchase up to $25,000 in common stock per calendar year.
912750_16_ITEM8_P181_S3	Employees of our China business are not eligible to participate in the plan.

912750_16_ITEM8_P182_S2	The fair value of the options granted was determined using the Black-Scholes option valuation method assuming no dividends, a risk-free interest rate of 0.12% , an expected life of six months and weighted-average volatility of 49.41% .

912750_16_ITEM8_P188_S0	In September 2013, the Compensation and Management Development Committee of the Board approved the SVAP to be administered under the 2011 Plan.
912750_16_ITEM8_P189_S0	The SVAP paid substantially all full-time domestic, nonexecutive employees a cash payment based on a percentage of salary upon each incremental $5 increase in our 30 -calendar day average share price.
912750_16_ITEM8_P189_S1	Each price threshold could be reached only once during the term of the program.
912750_16_ITEM8_P190_S0	The first price threshold that triggered a payment under the SVAP was $27.50 during the fourth quarter of 2013.
912750_16_ITEM8_P190_S1	The second and third price thresholds for the SVAP were $32.50 and $37.50 , respectively, which were reached during the second quarter of 2014.
912750_16_ITEM8_P190_S2	The fourth price threshold for the SVAP of $42.50 was reached in July 2014.
912750_16_ITEM8_P190_S3	Each of the first four SVAP payments was approximately $13 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P190_S4	No liability existed at December 31, 2015 as the SVAP's performance period ended on that date.
912750_16_ITEM8_P191_S0	We sponsor a post-retirement medical plan that covers all retired employees until they reach age 65 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P191_S1	At December 31, 2015 , both our accumulated benefit obligation and our accrued benefit costs were $18 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P191_S2	Our net periodic benefit cost was approximately $3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , and approximately $2 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P192_S0	The expected future benefit payments under our post-retirement medical plan for the next ten years include $6 million for the five-year period 2016 through 2020 and $9 million for the five-year period 2021 through 2025.
912750_16_ITEM8_P193_S0	During 2010, our Board of Directors, with the recommendation of the Compensation Management Development Committee, approved a new annual cash incentive compensation plan for all employees (the 2011 Annual Incentive Plan).
912750_16_ITEM8_P194_S0	Under the 2011 Annual Incentive Plan, the Compensation Management Development Committee determines the annual award pool for all employees based upon a number of factors including the Company s performance against stated performance goals and in comparison with peer companies in our industry.
912750_16_ITEM8_P194_S1	All employees are eligible if employed on October 1 and December 31 of the performance period.
912750_16_ITEM8_P194_S2	Beginning with the year ended December 31, 2010, our annual cash incentive compensation is paid in a single payment to employees during the first quarter after the end of the performance period.
912750_16_ITEM8_P195_S0	Total incentive compensation expense under the 2011 Annual Incentive Plan for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 was $41 million , $45 million and $40 million , respectively.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S0	We sponsor a 401(k) profit sharing plan under Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S1	This plan covers all of our employees, excluding those of our foreign subsidiaries.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S2	We match $1.00 for each $1.00 of employee deferral, with our contribution not to exceed 8% of an employee s salary, subject to limitations imposed by the IRS.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S3	We also sponsor a highly compensated employee deferred compensation plan.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S4	This non-qualified plan allows an eligible employee to defer a portion of his or her salary or bonus on an annual basis.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S5	We match $1.00 for each $1.00 of employee deferral, with our contribution not to exceed 8% of an employee s salary, subject to limitations imposed by the plan.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S6	Our contribution with respect to each participant in the deferred compensation plan is reduced by the amount of contribution made by us to our 401(k) plan for that participant.
912750_16_ITEM8_P196_S7	Our combined contributions to these two plans was $7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , and $10 million for each of the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S0	In April 2015, we announced plans to combine our onshore Gulf Coast and Rocky Mountain business units into our newly-created Western Region, which is managed from The Woodlands, Texas.
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S1	Our decision to restructure the organization, which only affected our domestic business, was primarily in response to the current oil and gas commodity price environment.
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S2	These changes better utilize our resources and improve cost efficiencies in operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S3	Substantially all one-time restructuring-related costs were incurred by December 31, 2015.
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S4	These costs did not materially affect our cash flows or results of operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S5	We abandoned our Denver, Colorado office space during the third quarter of 2015 and recorded a loss for the remaining contracted payments net of expected sublease income.
912750_16_ITEM8_P197_S6	We will close our North Houston (Greenspoint area) office in the first quarter of 2016.

912750_16_ITEM8_P204_S0	In 2013, we met the criteria to classify our Malaysia business as held for sale and discontinued operations.
912750_16_ITEM8_P204_S1	In February 2014, we closed the sale of our Malaysia business to SapuraKencana Petroleum Berhad (SapuraKencana), a Malaysian public company, for $898 million .
912750_16_ITEM8_P204_S2	As a result of the sale, we recorded a gain in the first quarter of 2014 of approximately $388 million ( $252 million , after tax).
912750_16_ITEM8_P204_S3	In the fourth quarter of 2014, we recorded an allowance against a receivable from SapuraKencana and reduced the previously recognized gain by $15 million ( $10 million , after tax) due to uncertainty associated with collectability.
912750_16_ITEM8_P204_S4	In April 2015, we initiated a notice of dispute related to the final post-close settlement, which was countered by SapuraKencana.
912750_16_ITEM8_P204_S5	We believe the dispute may result in arbitration proceedings.

912750_16_ITEM8_P206_S1	As a result of our December 2012 decision to repatriate earnings from our international operations, we experienced higher international effective tax rates due to these earnings being taxed in both the U.S. and the local country.
912750_16_ITEM8_P206_S2	The effective tax rate for our discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2014 was 37% , as the majority of our income from discontinued operations resulted from the gain on the sale of our Malaysia business, which was only taxable in the U.S.
912750_16_ITEM8_P206_S3	The effective tax rate for our discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2013 was 58% due to our international earnings being taxed in both the U.S and the local country.

912750_16_ITEM8_P211_S1	(4) During the quarter ended March 31, 2014, we sold our Malaysia business and recorded a gain of approximately $388 million ( $252 million , after tax).
912750_16_ITEM8_P211_S2	During the fourth quarter of 2014, we reduced the previously recognized gain by $15 million ( $10 million , after tax) due to recording an allowance against a receivable.
912750_16_ITEM8_P211_S3	See Note 19 , "Discontinued Operations," for additional information.

912750_16_ITEM8_P216_S0	Users of this information should be aware that the process of estimating quantities of proved and proved developed oil and gas reserves is very complex, requiring significant subjective decisions in the evaluation of all available geological, engineering and economic data for each reservoir.
912750_16_ITEM8_P216_S1	The data for a given reservoir also may change substantially over time as a result of numerous factors, including additional development activity, evolving production history and continual reassessment of the viability of production under varying economic conditions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P216_S2	Consequently, material revisions to existing reserve estimates may occur from time to time.
912750_16_ITEM8_P217_S0	All reserve information in this report is based on estimates prepared by our petroleum engineering staff and is the responsibility of management.
912750_16_ITEM8_P217_S1	The preparation of our oil and gas reserves estimates is completed in accordance with our prescribed internal control procedures, which include verification of data input into our reserves forecasting and economics evaluation software, as well as multi-discipline management reviews.
912750_16_ITEM8_P217_S2	The technical employee responsible for overseeing the preparation of the reserves estimates has a Bachelor of Science in Petroleum Engineering, with more than 30 years of industry experience (including over 20 years of experience in reserve estimation).
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S0	Our reserves estimates are made using available geological and reservoir data as well as production performance data.
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S1	These estimates, made by our petroleum engineering staff, are reviewed annually with management and revised, either upward or downward, as warranted by additional data.
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S2	The data reviewed includes, among other things, seismic data, well logs, production tests, reservoir pressures, and individual well and field performance data.
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S3	The data incorporated into our interpretations includes structure and isopach maps, individual well and field performance and other engineering and geological work products such as material balance calculations and reservoir simulation to arrive at conclusions about individual well and field projections.
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S4	Additionally, offset performance data, operating expenses, capital costs and product prices factor into estimating quantities of reserves.
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S5	Revisions are necessary due to changes in, among other things, reservoir performance, prices, economic conditions and governmental regulations, as well as changes in the expected recovery rates associated with development drilling.
912750_16_ITEM8_P218_S6	Sustained decreases in prices, for example, may cause a reduction in some reserves due to reaching economic limits sooner.
912750_16_ITEM8_P219_S0	The following is a discussion of our proved reserves and reserve additions and revisions.
912750_16_ITEM8_P220_S0	Our proved crude oil and condensate reserves at year-end 2015 were 207 million barrels compared to 301 million barrels and 270 million barrels at year-end 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
912750_16_ITEM8_P220_S1	Our proved NGL reserves at year-end 2015 were 84 million barrels compared to 76 million barrels and 68 million barrels at year-end 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
912750_16_ITEM8_P220_S2	Our proved natural gas reserves at year-end 2015 were 1.3 Tcf compared to 1.6 Tcf at year-end 2014 and 2013 .
912750_16_ITEM8_P220_S3	Liquids comprised about 57% , 58% and 55% of our proved reserves at year-end 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S0	During 2015, our proved reserves decreased 136 MMBOE primarily as a result of negative revisions of 286 MMBOE resulting from commodity price decreases.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S1	Price revisions were partially offset by positive revisions of 24 MMBOE and cost structure improvement revisions of 88 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S2	During 2015, we added proved reserves (through extensions, discoveries, improved recovery and other additions) of 102 MMBOE, sold non-strategic assets of 8 MMBOE and produced 56 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S3	During 2014, our proved reserves increased 33 MMBOE primarily as a result of extensions, discoveries and other additions of 72 MMBOE, purchases of 9 MMBOE, infill drilling revisions of 77 MMBOE and positive price revisions of 3 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S4	These were partially offset by negative revisions of 29 MMBOE resulting from development plan changes and well performance.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S5	During 2014, we sold non-strategic asset reserves in the Granite Wash and Malaysia of 49 MMBOE and produced 50 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S6	During 2013, our proved reserves increased 46 MMBOE primarily as a result of additions (through extensions, discoveries, improved recovery and other additions) of 82 MMBOE, infill drilling revisions of 75 MMBOE and positive price revisions of 10 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S7	These were partially offset by negative revisions of 71 MMBOE resulting from development plan changes and well performance.
912750_16_ITEM8_P221_S8	During 2013, we sold non-strategic asset reserves of 1 MMBOE and produced 49 MMBOE.
912750_16_ITEM8_P222_S0	The following table sets forth our total net proved reserves and our total net proved developed and undeveloped reserves as of December 31, 2012, 2013 , 2014 and 2015 and the changes in our total net proved reserves during the three-year period ended December 31, 2015 :
912750_16_ITEM8_P223_S0	_________________ (1) All of our reserves in China are associated with production sharing contracts and are calculated using the economic interest method.
912750_16_ITEM8_P223_S1	We used the economic interest method in Malaysia until we sold our Malaysia business in 2014.
912750_16_ITEM8_P224_S0	_________________ (1) All of our reserves in China are associated with production sharing contracts and are calculated using the economic interest method.
912750_16_ITEM8_P224_S1	We used the economic interest method in Malaysia until we sold our Malaysia business in 2014.

912750_16_ITEM15_P15_S0	ARTICLE I DEFINITIONS AND CONSTRUCTION 1.1 Definitions .
912750_16_ITEM15_P15_S1	Where the following words and phrases appear in the Plan, they shall have the respective meanings set forth below, unless their context clearly indicates to the contrary.
912750_16_ITEM15_P16_S0	A memorandum bookkeeping account, excluding a Stock Account, established on the records of the Company for a Member that is credited with amounts determined in accordance with Article III of the Plan.
912750_16_ITEM15_P16_S1	As of any determination date, a Member s benefit under the Plan shall be equal to the amount credited to his Account as of such date.
912750_16_ITEM15_P16_S2	A Member shall have a 100% nonforfeitable interest in his Account at all times.
912750_16_ITEM15_P17_S0	(b) Board : The Board of Directors of the Company.
912750_16_ITEM15_P17_S1	(c) Base Salary : The base rate of cash compensation paid by the Company to or for the benefit of a Member for services rendered or labor performed while a Member including base pay a Member could have received in cash in lieu of (A) deferrals pursuant to Section 3.1 and (B) contributions made on his behalf to any qualified plan maintained by the Company or to any cafeteria plan under Section 125 of the Code maintained by the Company.
912750_16_ITEM15_P17_S2	(d) Bonus Compensation : With respect to any Member for a Plan Year, an amount awarded under the Newfield Employee 1993 Incentive Compensation Plan or the Newfield Exploration Company 2003 Incentive Compensation Plan.
912750_16_ITEM15_P18_S0	(vi) as a result of or in connection with a contested election of directors, the Persons who were directors of the Company before such election cease to constitute a majority of the Board.
912750_16_ITEM15_P18_S1	Notwithstanding the foregoing, the definition of Change of Control shall not include (A) any merger, consolidation, reorganization, sale, lease, exchange, or similar transaction involving solely the Company and one or more Persons that were wholly owned, directly or indirectly, by the Company immediately prior to such event or (B) any event that is not a change in control for purposes of Section 409A. For purposes of this definition, Person shall mean any individual, partnership, corporation, limited liability company, trust, incorporated or unincorporated organization or association or other legal entity of any kind.
912750_16_ITEM15_P19_S0	The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S0	(g) Compensation Committee : The Compensation Management Development Committee of the Board.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S1	(h) Company : Newfield Exploration Company.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S2	(i) Company Deferrals : Deferrals made by the Company on a Member s behalf pursuant to Section 3.5.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S3	(j) Company Stock : The common stock of Newfield Exploration Company.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S4	(k) Effective Date : April 1, 1997.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S5	(l) Member : Each individual who is a Member pursuant to Article II.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S6	(m) Plan : The Newfield Exploration Company Deferred Compensation Plan.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S7	(n) Plan Committee : The individual or committee that is authorized by the Compensation Committee to administer the Plan.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S8	The Plan Committee may delegate pursuant to a written authorization (including, by way of illustration, through a contract, memorandum, or other written delegation document) any or all if its responsibilities set forth in the Plan to one or more individuals, committees or service providers.
912750_16_ITEM15_P20_S9	In any case where the Plan refers to the Plan Committee, such reference is deemed to be a reference to any delegate of the Plan Committee appointed for such purpose.
912750_16_ITEM15_P21_S0	The twelve-consecutive month period commencing January 1 of each year; provided, however, that the first Plan Year began on April 1, 1997 and ended on December 31, 1997.
912750_16_ITEM15_P22_S0	(p) Section 409A : Section 409A of the Code and any applicable regulations or rulings thereunder.
912750_16_ITEM15_P22_S1	(q) Separation from Service : A separation from service within the meaning of Section 409A(a)(2)(A)(i) of the Code.
912750_16_ITEM15_P23_S0	(r) Specified Employee : A "specified employee" within the meaning of Section 409A(a)(2)(B)(i) of the Code.
912750_16_ITEM15_P23_S1	The bookkeeping account specifically established for a Member that includes amounts determined in accordance with Section 3.6(b).
912750_16_ITEM15_P24_S0	(t) Trust : The trust, if any, established under the Trust Agreement.
912750_16_ITEM15_P24_S1	The agreement, if any, entered into between the Company and the Trustee pursuant to Article VIII.
912750_16_ITEM15_P24_S2	(v) Trust Fund : The funds and properties, if any, held pursuant to the provisions of the Trust Agreement, together with all income, profits and increments thereto.
912750_16_ITEM15_P24_S3	(w) Trustee : The trustee or trustees appointed by the Plan Committee who are qualified and acting under the Trust Agreement at any time.
912750_16_ITEM15_P24_S4	Wherever appropriate herein, words used in the singular shall be considered to include the plural and words used in the plural shall be considered to include the singular.
912750_16_ITEM15_P24_S5	The masculine gender, where appearing in the Plan, shall be deemed to include the feminine gender.
